college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. J Weenink', 'dr. KJ Grit', 'dr. MA Koopmanschap', 'dr. VT Reckers - Droog', 'FA Tallgren', 'K Trujillo Jara', 'MJ Kersing, MSc', 'prof.dr. RA Bal', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']
text:
Inhoud
Conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare are rarely merely technical problems. They tend to have profound moral dimensions which are often overlooked. Policy-advisors as well as managers need to be sensitive to the moral aspects of conflicts and dilemmas occurring in healthcare. Sensibility for the moral side of problems (in healthcare as well as anywhere else) is not self-evident. It is something which must be acquired. In addition, moral problems are also problems which can be solved. Moral reasoning is something that can be learned.

The course introduces students to moral philosophy. What is morality? What constitutes a moral dilemma? Why be moral? Is there truth in morality? What qualifies an act morally? What constitutes moral character? Following these meta-ethical questions, the course surveys major normative ethical theories (including utilitarianism, rights theory and virtue theory), describes methods of moral justification in healthcare ethics, addresses the problem of moral status and agency (what rights people are due, and when) and examines the moral characteristics of the basic relationships (e.g. professionals-patients and clients) inherent to healthcare.
 
Drawing from contemporary research, case studies and real-life examples, students will learn how the fundamental moral principles of autonomy, benevolence and justice can be expanded to apply to various conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare, from whether or not to withhold or withdraw life-sustaining treatments, to such diverse issues as the legislation of organ donation (opt-in or opt-out?), euthanasia and fulfilled lives, life style choices, access to collectively financed healthcare and solidarity, and expensive drugs and the worth of human life.
At the end of the course, students will have learned that the reasoning typical of the disciplines constituting health sciences, such as (health) economics and (health) law, are but different ways to approach normative problems in healthcare, that there is a common (ethical) language, and that there is a way to include them all when faced with such problems.

In interactive lectures students will be made familiar with the basics of philosophical ethics, healthcare ethics and moral reasoning. In the seminars the theory will be put to practice. During the course students will apply the same method of moral reasoning to a variety of moral problems in healthcare in ever smaller groups. Finally, the individual student is expected to write an essay, providing a moral question of his or her choice, but approved by the staff, by the best possible answer, in the way taught in the seminars.
Leerdoelen
  • The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of moral philosophy
  • The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of health care ethics
  • The student acquires basic moral reasoning skills
  • The student is able to apply basic moral reasoning skills to real-life moral dilemmas in healthcare
  • The student engages actively in moral discussions
  • The student is able to hold a moral position convincingly, expressed in a well-written essay, based on well-researched arguments and sound logic

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['PJG Dohmen, MSc', 'prof.dr.ir. EM van Raaij']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
In this course we will focus on the procurement process and on value chain management in the healthcare sector. In many countries, healthcare represents one of the largest sectors of the economy; healthcare spend often amounts to 10% of a country’s GDP. This course builds on the key concepts as taught in the core course Purchasing & Supply Management (BM05SCM). This course expands into areas that are not only relevant in healthcare, but also in other sectors, such as services triads, performance-based contracting, best value procurement, European tendering, cooperative purchasing, and negotiation skills. 

In healthcare value chains two types of purchasing can be distinguished: purchasing of healthcare and purchasing for healthcare. In purchasing of healthcare, which is done by for instance healthcare insurers, ‘healthcare’ is the service that is purchased. In purchasing for healthcare a diverse set of goods and services is purchased (e.g. catering, temporary labour and medical equipment). 

A significant amount of money is spent in the healthcare industry on a yearly basis, which makes that there is a large potential for the purchasing profession to decrease spend, improve quality and increase innovation as well as efficiency. In this course we connect management theory about purchasing with specific characteristics of the healthcare industry. 

 

Leerdoelen

Learning Objectives
Upon completing this course, students:

1.           Can explain the importance of professional purchasing and supply management to create value in healthcare systems and justify why high purchasing maturity is important;
2.           Understand the different ways in which value can be operationalized and apply this knowledge to a variety of stakeholders in the healthcare system;
3.           Understand the role that incentives play in buyer-supplier relationships and evaluate which incentives are appropriate to create value in such relationships;
4.           Understand the importance of different types of relationships within and between organisations and compare the advantages and disadvantages of different ways to structure and govern such relationships;
5.           Understand the principles of the EU regulations on public procurement and evaluate how such regulations impact purchasing for care and purchasing of care;
6.           Can articulate a question for a guest lecturer based on their knowledge of purchasing of care and purchasing for care;
7.           Can apply their knowledge of purchasing of care and purchasing for care to cases of real healthcare organizations, diseases/conditions, and/or patient groups, and create an argumentation how purchasing and supply management can deliver value in that case.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['PJG Dohmen, MSc', 'prof.dr.ir. EM van Raaij']
text:
Inhoud Health care providers are dependent on suppliers for the production and delivery of the services they provide to their customers. In the same vein, health care financers (such as health insurers) are dependent on the health care providers to supply health care services to their clients. In both cases, the purchasing function has the responsibility to secure external inputs (goods, services, knowledge, people) from the suppliers against the best possible conditions.

In the health care supply chain, we distinguish between purchasing of health care and purchasing for health care. When we speak of purchasing of health care, the health care is the product that is purchased (e.g., care or cure purchased by health insurers). When we speak of purchasing for health care, we are looking at a broad spectrum of goods and services needed by health care providers, such as medical devices, temporary labor, catering, and much more. Health care represents a considerable portion of public (and private) spending, and therefore, various entities (such as the WHO, as well as the Dutch NZa and RVS) are pointing towards professional purchasing management as a possible contributor to cost containment, quality improvement, innovation, and productivity enhancement in the health care sector.

In this course, we connect management theory in the area of purchasing and supply management to the specific characteristics of the health care sector.

  Leerdoelen Upon completing this course, students:
 
Can explain the importance of professional purchasing and supply management to create value in healthcare systems and justify why high purchasing maturity is important;
Understand the different ways in which value can be operationalized and apply this knowledge to a variety of stakeholders in the healthcare system;
Understand the importance of different types of relationships within and between organisations and compare the advantages and disadvantages of different ways to structure and govern such relationships;
Understand the principles of the EU regulations on public procurement and evaluate how such regulations impact purchasing for care and purchasing of care;
Can articulate a question for a guest lecturer based on their knowledge of purchasing of care and purchasing for care;
Can apply their knowledge of purchasing of care and purchasing for care to cases of real healthcare organizations, diseases/conditions, and/or patient groups, and create an argumentation how purchasing and supply management can create value in that case.

lecturers: ['mr. A Schoneveld', 'mr. FJHL Makkinga', 'prof.mr.dr. AW Schep']
text:
Inhoud Het vak Heffingen lokale overheden behandelt de gemeentelijke belastingen en retributies en plaatst dit specialistische vakgebied in perspectief ten opzichte van het gehele fiscale stelsel.
Daarbij is, naast kennis van de lokale belastingen, die veelal een geheel eigen karakter hebben, ook inzicht in de structuur van dit nog steeds groeiende belastinggebied van belang. De verbondenheid van de belastingverordeningen dient kritisch te kunnen worden beoordeeld. Gegeven de veelvuldige wijzigingen (ook in dit deel van het belastingrecht) dient inzicht te worden verkregen in de materiële gevolgen van implementatie van nieuwe regelgeving, waaronder het steeds bredere gebruik van de WOZ-waarde, bijvoorbeeld in de inkomstenbelasting en in de vennootschapsbelasting (de beperking van de afschrijving op gebouwen ingevolge de Wet Werken aan Winst).
Heffingen lokale overheden richt zich op een uitwerking van diverse belastingen en rechten die gemeenten, provincies en waterschappen heffen, alsmede op de Wet waardering onroerende zaken, haar uitvoeringsregels en de taxatiemethoden.
Daarnaast komt de toepassing van rechtsbeginselen in ruime mate aan bod, zoals de werking van het gelijkheidsbeginsel en het evenredigheidsbeginsel. Leerdoelen Na dit vak:
 
  • heeft de student kennis en inzicht in de grondslagen en beginselen van het lokale belastingrecht alsmede de verhouding van dit belastingrecht tot andere rechtsgebieden
  • heeft de student grondige kennis en inzicht in de essentialia van de lokale belastingen en retributies, alsmede in de werking van de Wet WOZ
  • kan de student het gelijkheids- en het evenredigheidsbeginsel toepassen op de lokale belastingen en retributies, alsmede andere rechts- en fiscale beginselen toepassen
  • heeft de student kennis en inzicht in de totstandkoming en inhoud van verordeningen en lokale belastingen, alsmede in de heffing en invordering van deze heffingen
  • heeft de student kennis en inzicht in de maatschappelijke rol van het lokale belastingrecht en de acceptatie van burgers van deze heffingen
  • kan de student juridische teksten, waaronder wetgeving (mede hieronder begrepen verdragen), jurisprudentie en wetenschappelijke literatuur begrijpen, analyseren en kritisch beoordelen
  • kan de student binnen een bepaalde tijdsspanne antwoord geven op fiscaalrechtelijke casus uit de lokale belastingpraktijk in de vorm van een schriftelijk stuk
  • heeft de student vaardigheid opgedaan om te komen tot een onderbouwde juridische argumentatie met betrekking tot de werking van rechtsbeginselen, essentialia van belastingen en de werking van de Wet WOZ, en de bewijsvoering
  • heeft de student inzicht gekregen in de werking van het fiscale bestuurs(proces)recht door analyse van WOZ- en andere fiscale bezwaar- en beroepsprocedures en door oefening van argumentatie in die procedures

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. F. Petrij', 'E. Rip', 'MSc R.L. Lechner']

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['prof.dr. B Wubs']
text:
Inhoud

The fashion industry is a paradigmatic sector of post-industrial economies, whose products increasingly rely on symbolic and aesthetic considerations as well as on local heritage and specificities. The fashion industry revolves around a myriad of key locations around the world, yet this has been the case for an extended period of time. A polycentric geography of fashion emerged, integrating traditional supply chains with digital technologies. Some luxury brands, such as Louis Vuitton, are even engaging with blockchain to prove the authenticity of their products. Topics covered in the course, among others: place, space and heritage in the fashion industry, storytelling, craftsmanship, temporary fashion clusters, and policies for fashion. In particular, storytelling appears to be an important tool for the fashion industry due to the necessity to differentiate the various products or brands and to add emotional value to them. Heritage and tradition are at the core of storytelling. Even new fashion products and brands are imbued with a historical flavor and sense of legendary quality, with the help of storytelling and revived craftsmanship. Given the rise of sustainability concerns, storytelling and craftsmanship, and in general heritage, are gaining momentum for the fashion industry and other creative industries too.

 

Leerdoelen

·         Students have a thorough knowledge and understanding of how the fashion industry and heritage are intertwined.

·         Students can analyze the place, space, and heritage of the fashion industry from business history and cultural economics perspectives.

·         Students are able to present and discuss the results of their analysis with peers and with fashion stakeholders.

 

​

lecturers: ['prof.dr. RBJM Welten']
text:
Inhoud Het moderne subject als autonoom en rationeel individu werd geboren in de gedachten van Descartes en Kant, zo wordt beweerd. Maar tijdens de 20e eeuw tot heden trekken veel filosofen de vrijheid, rationaliteit en coherentie van het subject in twijfel. Is het subject wel zo autonoom en vrij als het meent te zijn? Is het wel wat het denkt dat het is? In welke mate zijn we bepaald door de maatschappelijke, culturele, economische en politieke aard?
 
In deze cursus zullen we nagaan hoe het huidige beeld van de mens als een autonoom, rationeel individu zich heeft ontwikkeld en op welke grenzen het stuit. We bespreken klassieke teksten uit de subjectfilosofie en analyseren de kritiek aan deze posities van denkers uit de 20e en 21e eeuw waaronder Freud, Kierkegaard, Camus, Sartre, De Beauvoir, Barthes, Lacan en Žižek. Daarbij zal duidelijk worden dat niet enkel het concept van het subject, maar ook het filosofische denken zelf altijd ingebed ligt in omstandigheden van maatschappelijke, culturele en politieke aard en dat die elkaar over en weer beïnvloeden. Leerdoelen



De werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten Filosofie.

Aan het einde van de cursus heeft de student/e inzicht in de verschillende concepten van het subject via de wordingsgeschiedenis daarvan en de kritische uiteenzettingen daarmee in de moderne tijd. Ze/hij is in staat om de argumenten in de behandelde teksten te identificeren en samen te vatten. Zij/hij geeft een onderbouwde redenering over de deugdelijkheid van de genoemde kritiekpunten (die gericht zijn tegen het concept van een autonoom een rationeel subject).

Inhoud
Instructors: 
prof. dr. D. Vigo (VU).
 
Course content:
Heuristics form an indispensable tool for everyone working in operations management because problems arising from practice are often too hard to solve exactly and heuristics are relatively simple methods that may provide feasible solutions of good quality. The course is about heuristics to solve general problems but uses logistics optimization problems such as the vehicle routing problem as examples of specific implementations. The field of routing is in fact so rich that virtually all published heuristic ideas have been applied to it. The course is further divided into two parts, each of which first covers general problems and then focuses on routing:
  • Classical heuristics to construct a feasible solution and improvement heuristics based on structured local search
  • Metaheuristics aiming at escaping local optima
  • All methods will be illustrated through actual implementations in high level language.
Leerdoelen

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

  • Identify problems which will require heuristics for their solution; identify the most appropriate heuristic for the solution of a problem.
  • Discuss the characteristics of the main heuristici techniques by considering their efficiency and effectiveness; develop implementations of heuristics for optimization and vehicle routing problems.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. MF van Dijck', 'dr. SK Manickam', 'E van Wingerden', 'J Beocanin', 'R van Lent, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

This course offers an overview of how to find, analyse and use primary, secondary and tertiary sources for historical research. Students will learn how they can find and evaluate these sources using traditional resources, such as bibliographies, book reviews and reference works, but they also  have  to  familiarise  themselves  with new research methods  such as  online  databases  and Internet sources. Students  not only  learn how to find these sources, they  also acquire  the  skills  to  organise  and evaluate  all this  information. They can find  this  information on the  internet,  but they  also  have  to  visit libraries  and archives  to  collect the most relevant data for their research. Students will be introduced to historiographical debates and will learn how to identify debates relevant to their research. They will also learn to write a structural analysis of these historiographical debates.

Leerdoelen

Students will learn how scholarly information is communicated and how they have to credit other academics’ work in their research. They can find and evaluate primary, secondary and tertiary sources, and identify and use different types of sources in historical research. Students  will be able to find relevant source material in libraries, archives and on the internet, using digital tools for historical research. Students will learn how to write a structural analysis and to analyse historiographical debates.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. TIN Davidson']
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
Leaders are key players in organizational functioning because they critically affect the people they work with—both inside and outside of their organization. Leaders are in a unique position to mobilise employees to excel and contribute to the organisation’s mission and vision. At the same time, however, they may also be a primary source of conflict and demotivation. Understanding what makes for high performance leadership as well as where leadership can go wrong, therefore, is of critical importance to any aspiring leader; and in particular for HR professionals who may come to take the lead of the HR organization, as well as facilitate the process of leadership in their organization. 

In this course, we address one key question: “what makes an effective leader?” from a range of different theoretical perspectives (e.g., social identity, visionary leadership) and cast in the context of contemporary workplace trends (e.g., demographic change, digitization). Through a sequence of readings, lectures, cases, and experiential exercises, students learn to understand and apply state-of-the-art leadership theories, analyse and evaluate the determinants of leadership successes and failures, as well as apply these learnings to make recommendations for real-world leadership challenges. 

Leerdoelen

Learning Objectives
At the end of the course, you should be able to…

  1. Understand and apply the state-of-the art theories in leadership at the individual/relational, team, and organizational levels (i.e., vision communication, identity-based leadership)
  2. Analyze and evaluate the determinants of leadership successes and failure
  3. Develop theoretically sound and practically relevant recommendations for “better” leadership vis-à-vis contemporary leadership challenges
  4. Practice and develop your leadership through self-awareness, experimentation, and reflection
  5. Develop a critical, evidence-based perspective on leadership issues.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. D. Jaarsma', 'E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen']

text:
Inhoud The discipline of sociology was established during (and to make sense of) the process of modernisation. A core characteristic of modernisation is rapid social change, and sociology theorises and studies such changes by comparing traditional societies to modern societies. The perspectives that were developed and the topics addressed by the founders of the discipline are still relevant today, because they regard issues as socioeconomic inequality, social order and deviance, the role of religion and ideology, gender relations, what it means to live in an urbanised world, the relation of individuals with society. In this course we learn about these classic perspectives by looking at contemporary societies. We will learn to apply the ‘sociological imagination’ to everyday life as well as study the classic sociological questions using present-day cases. Assessment consists of a final exam and an essay.

  Leerdoelen After this course, students will be able to describe and apply the three most important sociological perspectives (functionalism, conflict sociology, symbolic interactionism) to issues such as modernization, inequality, cohesion and individualization.
In addition, students are able to reproduce the meaning of and theory formation around the following key concepts: Scientific paradigms; Identity performance; Political distrust; Gender segregation in the labour market; Deviance and social problems; Religion and Atheism; Sociology of Globalization.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen', 'prof. dr. Y. Elgersma']

course_title: Historical Culture in a Globalising World
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. RJ Adriaansen']
text:
Inhoud

The past is not simply gone. It permeates people's lives through memory and imagination, and offers an orientation in time. Telling stories about what happened in the past plays a key role in the construction of personal and collective identities. Creating a historical narrative through emplotment means establishing a sequence of selected historical events that makes the events meaningful to a contemporary audience in a specific way. Historical narratives fuel calls to action of social and political movements. Tragic stories of historical injustices support calls for reparations or for emancipation. Governments go to great lengths to control historical narration and interpretation to legitimize the political entities they govern, or to legitimize their policies. Also individuals historicize their own lives through narration in order to deal with expected and unexpected challenges and opportunities.

A central concept to understand these and similar processes is historical culture. The concept refers to historical narratives and performances, to the infrastructure of the historical field which makes it possible for people to deal with past, and to different conceptions of history that enable historical imagination.
This course provides theoretical reflection on historical culture and discusses methods of analyzing narrative plotlines. We will study several cases, such as the narrative scripts of historical reconciliation committees, the politics of descent in political speeches, and the destruction of cultural heritage.

Leerdoelen
•     Students can analyze transformations in cultural and political attitudes towards the past
•     Students can defend a theoretically and empirically informed position in contemporary memory debates
•     Students can cooperatively advise policy makers on strategies to deal with contentious issues in historical culture

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. SK Manickam', 'JA Seijbel, MSC MA', 'L Zurné, MA']
text:
Inhoud Images can have a major mobilizing force. For instance, cartoons of a lazy stadholder William V encouraged the Dutch patriots to rebel against the Orangist family; and in the late 1960s, photo's about the Vietnam war in   the  newspapers  triggered  mass  protests  against  the  American  government.  The same goes for representations of a shared, contested, or imagined past. These images of the past can evoke feelings of recognition, resistance or nostalgia, and can be used to educate, entertain, commemorate, unite, or to mobilize people.
This course focuses on the process of historical representation  and imagination since the late 18th century, as well als on the  contents, narrative,  functions and  impact of historical representations. We will discuss some interesting case-studies in which we apply the concepts from the literature. Students will elaborate on the concepts and their applications in the form of written work and a group presentation. Leerdoelen
Students acquire knowledge about the process of representing and imagining the past in different contexts and media, such as monuments, exhibitions, commemorations, and historical re-enactments. They can contextualize and critically assess these images of the past in view of its functions for specific communities. They are capable to produce written papers and oral presentations on relevant topics of this course, based on the discussed concepts.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['AF Heslinga', 'dr. JJ Euwe', 'dr. V Baptist', 'prof.dr. B Wubs']
text:
Inhoud

The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4 , preparing the students for writing their master’s thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, where after students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:
 
Term 2: eight plenary meetings
-  discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
-  design of a research proposal
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
 
Term 3: three plenary meetings
-  carrying out research
-  critical discussion of the research proposals
-  discussion of and information on possible research methods
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
 
Term  4 : three plenary meetings
-  wrapping up research
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  presentation of the thesis research at master conference 
-  participation in discussions following presentations
 
The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4 .

Theme: Histories of Creativity and Innovation

The term Creative Industries is a relatively recent concept coined in the late 1990s by new labour in Britain. Ever since this contested concept has evolved into an important policy instrument of national and local governments, the European Union, and United Nations, as well as a lively academic discourse. The workshop aims to historicize the concept and explore the historical roots of the creative industries and aims to analyse different sectors of the industry, including fashion, art markets, film, radio, television, music, design, theatre, tourism and video games. Furthermore, this course looks at innovations within large and small firms and networks across a range of industries. It explores the role of institutions and organizations, in particular governments or similar gatekeeping structures, and the diversity of innovation processes and across different sectors of the economy in the long twentieth century. Finally, it focuses on the effects of innovation and creativity on economic growth, international competitiveness, and employment. Different theoretical approaches emphasising cultural, national, regional, local, and firm-based factors, will be explored and applied to case studies selected by the students.

Further information at the Thesis Market in October

Leerdoelen
  • Students can adequately and efficiently structure and conduct historical research
  • Students can critically assess and discuss the research design, data collection and methodology of their master’s thesis
  • Students can analyse, report and present their research findings
  • Students can present their ideas and work- in-progress
  • Students can constructively comment on the research of their peers

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. I Gusc', 'dr. MF van Dijck']
text:
Inhoud This course will teach students how to work with primary sources to uncover the recent history of diversity. Oral history and interviewing will b core skilsl in this course. The aim is to bring students in contact with refugees and migrants to record life, family and group histories. Students will learn how they have to conduct interviews in a professional and critical way without neglecting the emotional and ethical dimensions of such a conversation. They will discover the theoretical and practical dimensions of an oral history project during lectures and field work. The second part of the course will teach students how to analyse and map photographs in an urban context. Pictures can show how marginalised groups made use of public space and how their representations can be distorted by the gaze of dominant groups in society. The students will also make an attempt to use GIS software to place these photos in urban space. Leerdoelen
  • Students are able to use online oral history databases, to set up small oral history projects and to conduct interviews to collect data on diversity in urban societies
  • Students can critically analyse historical photographs to analyse diversity in urban societies.
  • Students are able to use methodologies from the digital humanities such as GIS and speech recognition tools to analyse historical data

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. O Lindemann']

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['BFM Hilkens', 'dr. JC Nierstrasz', 'dr. Y van Hoef', 'FAM Baas', 'N Sikkema', 'R van Lent, MSc']
text:
Inhoud This course starts with an overview of the major founders of the social sciences (Adam Smith, Karl Marx, Emile Durkheim and Max Weber). These early social scientists assume that the rise of modernity around 1800 was a milestone in world history. They believe that early modern society was profoundly transformed by industrialisation, secularisation, democratisation and urbanisation. This particular view on historical developments is heavily criticised by historians, because of its Eurocentric, deterministic and teleological approach. However, these theories still offer an interesting starting-point for historical research, because modernisation theories laid the foundation of our modern, western self-awareness and is still frequently used to explain global historical developments. Some of the twentieth-century elaborations of these early social theories are discussed in this course. A critical reflection on current developments is also part of this course.
  Leerdoelen
Students learn to identify and recognise similarities and differences between social sciences and history. They can define some key concepts of the social sciences and place them in their historical context. They can explain and critically analyse modernisation theories. They can connect social theory with empirical research based on historical sources.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['BC Fici, MA', 'DLA Velthuizen - Velthuizen, MA', 'dr. JC Nierstrasz', 'N Sikkema']
text:
Inhoud
In the early modern period, Western societies set their first steps towards modernity. In this process, they ultimately set off on a path diverging from the rest of the world. Most historians will agree on this part of the story, but it is still under debate how, why and when this divergence started. Did it    start with the American war of independence, the French Revolution and the Industrial Revolution or had the wheels of change already been set in motion long before? Did Europe feel born again as it set out to discover the unknown after the Plague? Were the religious 'dark-ages' eventually  enlightened by the Renaissance and reason? And to what extent did international trade provide the inspiration for and precede industrialisation? During this course, it will be critically assessed whether these changes were indigenous to Europe or should be viewed just as much as a result of Europe’s interaction with the rest of the world. In the lectures and tutorials, we will ask ourselves the question if historians have too easily projected their view of the world today on the past, instead of seeing early modern societies as different and unique in their own right.
 
Leerdoelen Students are introduced to the history of early modern societies between 1300 and 1750. They will acquire new insights into the structural changes that took place in Europe and in the wider world during this period. Students are able to analyse historical argumentative texts and use this skill of the so-called structure analysis in producing papers and an oral presentation.

lecturers: ['prof.dr. AC Gielen']
text:
Inhoud

The history of economic thought helps us to understand why economists think they way they do today. It describes how theoretical frameworks have changed over time.
Subjects include, among others:

  • Classical school
  • Marginalism
  • Neo-classical school
  • Keynes
  • and more recent economic approaches.
Leerdoelen
  • Know the basic schools of thought in economics, and understand how each of these contributed to the evolution of economics as a scientific discipline.
  • Relate historical economic theories to key concepts in modern economics.
  • Critically comment on historical economic texts.

lecturers: ['dr. E Dekker']
text:
Inhoud Lectures/seminars provide a general overview of the history of economics, with more detailed analysis of particular issues and problems, the precise coverage sometimes being varied to reflect the interests of those taking the course each year. Students are expected to read recommended materials beforehand, so that the lectures can focus on a discussion of the readings.
 
Topics likely to be covered (subject to students’ interests) include: Adam Smith, the market and trade; The Marginal Revolution – and “neoclassical” economics; Keynes, and the Keynesian Revolution; The rise of mathematical economics; The 1970s and after; Economics and other social sciences; Economists on method; Ethics and Welfare; Economists and ideology (and specific institutions).
 
Readings are selected to introduce students to a range of approaches to the subject. For example, Adam Smith is used to show how reading an economist through the lens of modern economics may be to impose ideas foreign to his or her thought; the lecture on Keynes introduces the idea of approaching the history of economics through an economist’s biography. Subsequent lectures give examples of work that debunks myths and which shows how changing philosophical presuppositions can change the way economic arguments are constructed. Leerdoelen By the end of this course, students should be able to:
 
1) Explain how economic ideas may be influenced by the context in which they arose and may reflect philosophical values and attitudes different from our own.
 
2) Provide and comment on examples of different approaches to writing the history of economics.
 
3) Identify and analyse some of the major themes that historians of economics have identified, such as the “marginal” revolution, the transition from interwar pluralism to postwar neoclassical economics, the Keynesian revolution, or the recent turn to applied economics.
 
4) Explain, using one or more examples, how the historian’s perspective on episodes in the history of economics may differ from that of a modern economist.

lecturers: ['prof.dr. RE Backhouse']
text:
Inhoud Instructor: Prof. R.E. Backhouse (Un. of Birmingham)
 
Course content:

This course offers a short introduction to the history of some important ideas in microeconomics, macroeconomics and empirical methods. A frequent theme will be that the writings of earlier generations of economists were frequently much less naïve than they are often made out to be and, in some cases, economists held views diametrically opposed to those with which they are often associated. For example, Adam Smith did not advocate the unchecked pursuit of self-interest, Maynard Keynes did not attribute unemployment to sticky wages, and Keynesian economists of the 1950s and 1960s well understood the potential for high demand to create accelerating inflation.

Sessions will involve a mixture of lecturing and discussion, and students will be expected to do a limited amount of reading before classes and to participate in discussions. One reason for this is so that students can turn the discussion to topics that interest them. More extensive reading will then be required for assignments, related to their own interest, which in many cases means students’ students’ research interests; the topics for these are worked out in consultation with the teacher.

The coverage can vary according to student demand, but topics that could be covered as part of the core include: the history of general equilibrium theory, game theory and welfare economics; the Keynesian revolution and monetarism; the history of the Phillips curve and DSGE modeling; the history of econometrics and empirical methods.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['BC Fici, MA', 'dr. JJ Euwe', 'dr. N da Silva Perez', 'dr. V Baptist']
text:
Inhoud
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" /><style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>From the middle of the eighteenth century, the industrial revolution, the spread of Enlightenment ideas and the rise of Romanticism, and the political revolutions in America and France created a structural transformation of Western Europe. A core notion that emerged, and that will serve as our central theme, is the contested idea of progress: the belief that humans are able to understand the world and improve it on the basis of that understanding. Each week we will focus on a specific theme that illustrates this basic idea and its critics. The first week is devoted to the rise of the new interventionist state from Napoleonic France on, the beginning of what would later be called the welfare state. During the second week we will study class conflicts in the nineteenth century, in connection with the increasing internationalization of the economy. Week three is devoted to the crisis of democracies during the interwar period, with a focus on the rise of fascism. In week four we will study the making of the modern material environment, especially the world-wide impact of modernist architecture, design, and city planning.</body>
</html>

Leerdoelen
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" /><style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>This course provides an introduction to the history of western societies since 1750. Structural changes in politics, culture and the economy are discussed. In addition, students are trained to close-read and interpret primary sources from this period and to report their findings in oral and written presentations.</body>
</html>
