college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. D. Jaarsma', 'E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen']
['D Rusu', 'prof.dr. JA van Ruler', 'prof.dr. L van Bunge']
text:
Inhoud Week 1. In intellectual history, few areas have recently been the subject of such intense scrutiny as the history of political thought. During the first week/part of this course the so-called ‘Cambridge School’ will be discussed. Established by eminent practising historians such as Quentin Skinner, J.G.A. Pocock, and John Dunn, it rose to prominence during the 1960s and 1970s, inspiring intellectual historians far beyond political theory.
 
Week 2. With his enormously influential political philosophy, Plato (c. 427-347) tried to solve the problem of conflicting interests of different parts of society. We will how his quest for harmony produced a detailed vision of an ideal society in The Republic; and we will discuss whether this vision entailed a totalitarian nightmare. Aristotle’s political philosophy revolves around the notion of man as a political animal who needs the political entity of the polis (city-state) in order to realise a happy and virtuous life; we will study Aristotle’s ideas for the best form of government and we will also critically examine his arguments for the inclusion and exclusion for certain specific groups.
 
Week 3. Though not very well-known for his political standpoints, Desiderius Erasmus’ Philosophy of Christ would form the basis of a standpoint on the ideal society that shares many aspects with what is understood by the rule of law in ‘free’ societies today. His moral conception of politics contrasts sharply to what we find in his friend Thomas More’s famous book on Utopia. Both positions and their intricate interdependence will be addressed. Without any doubt the best-known and most notorious work of the Italian humanist and philosopher Niccolò Machiavelli (1469-1527) is Il Principe (The Prince), first published in 1513. Notorious, because The Prince can be interpreted as a manual for would-be dictators whose goal is to attain and maintain power at all cost. Less notorious and famous, but certainly not less interesting is Machiavelli’s later more elaborate work, especially his Discourses on Livy (1531), where the classical history of ancient Rome forms the background stage of a discussion on how to form and maintain a republic. By comparing both works the students will learn about the basic principles of Machiavelli’s political philosophy.
 
Week 4. In the 19th century J.S. Mill (1806-1873) is the forefather of modern liberalism and feminism. According to On Liberty (1859) the greatest threat to personal liberty is no longer the state as in classic liberalism, but ‘public opinion’, which enforces conformity. Karl Marx (1818-1883) is the source of both social-democracy and communism. In the Communist Manifesto (1848) he outlines a ‘materialist’ theory of society, which sees society not as an integrated whole, but as a contingent set of conflicting groups (classes), and he links society to economy.

course_title: History of Western Arts and Culture
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['AC Crotta', 'dr. SR Driessen', 'EW Vermunt', 'I Vitola', 'LJLM De Strooper, MA', 'MF Rodriguez Rodriguez']
text:
Inhoud The course History of Western Arts and Culture provides a historical and chronological overview of Western art and culture from the late Middle Ages until the 21st century. Students get acquainted with the major developments in the visual arts, architecture, music, and literature from this period, against a historical background. It is demonstrated how the highlights from these disciplines originate from, reflect, and shape the socio-cultural context of their time, and how these historical developments continue to have their effects on contemporary culture.
History of Western Arts and Culture is intended for first-year students of the International Bachelor Arts and Culture Studies/Algemene Cultuurwetenschappen. The aim is to provide them with a historical and versatile foundation for their further studies. Students will acquire a historical overview of the main developments and trends in Western art and culture, and gain insight into how the various disciplines (visual arts, literature, architecture and music) are interrelated.  Furthermore, students will gain insight into the way in which art comes from, reflects on, and at the same time shapes the socio-cultural context of its time. Finally, students will acquire knowledge on how the position of the artist in relation to fellow artists, clients and the public has developed historically.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['AC Crotta', 'LJLM De Strooper, MA', 'prof.dr. FRR Vermeylen']
text:
Inhoud This course will provide an introduction to the history of the Dutch and European art markets, and the way the art trade functions as an intermediary between artist and audience. Various aspects dealing with the production, distribution and consumption of art will be discussed. Attention will be given - among other topics - to the innovations that were introduced to expand the market for works of art since early modern times. For instance the development and growing importance of art auctions from the seventeenth century until the present will be examined in detail, as well as other more recent developments such as the impact of new media on the art market.

Note: The maximum number of participants is 55. Leerdoelen The course seeks to familiarize the students with the history and functioning of early modern and modern art markets. They will be exposed to the recent findings concerning the socio-economic, but also the cultural and sociological framework in which works of art were and are produced, traded and consumed. An interdisciplinary approach will be pursued in order to gain insight into these phenomena.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. HC Dibbits', 'dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'dr. RJ Adriaansen', 'L Zurné, MA', 'prof.dr. CR Ribbens', 'prof.dr. RD Futselaar']
text:
Inhoud
The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4, preparing the students for writing their master's thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, whereafter students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:
 
Term 2: eight plenary meetings
  • discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
  • design of a research proposal
  • one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
 
 
Term 3: three plenary meetings
  • carrying out  research
  • critical discussion of the research proposals
  • discussion of and information on possible research methods
  • discussion of case studies and other work in progress
  • one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
 
 
Term 4: three plenary meetings
  • wrapping up research
  • discussion of case studies and other work in progress
  • one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
  • presentation of the thesis research at master conference in June

-  participation in discussions following presentations The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4 .

​Theme: History, memory and national identity
History and memory are analytically distinct, but overlapping concepts. The significance of both concepts is closely related to the emergence of nation states and their colonial empires, and to the professionalization of the pursuit of history. In this course we discuss the relationship between history and memory, and how this relationship has changed over time due to fundamental changes in society, such as the French Revolution, the emergence of mass culture, secularization, two world wars, new media, globalization, and transformations in historical scholarship. We will also study specific applications of these concepts in examples of (popular) historical culture, such as the construction of the nation state, heritage and public history. Leerdoelen
  • Students can adequately and efficiently structure and conduct historical research
  • Students can critically assess and discuss the research design, data collection and methodology of their master’s thesis
  • Students can analyse, report and present their research findings
  • Students can present their ideas and work- in-progress
  • Students can constructively comment on the research of their peers

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. I Gusc', 'dr. MF van Dijck', 'dr. S Bertrand', 'prof.dr. B Wubs', 'prof.dr. HAM Klemann']
text:
Inhoud Following the political revolutions of the late eighteenth century, the organising role of the state in a society that was no longer based on a hierarchy of orders and estates was fiercely debated in Europe and the United States. This debate was further intensified by the major effects of industrialisation in the English Midlands and subsequently elsewhere in Europe. The ideologies that still frame and inform debates today – conservatism, socialism, liberalism, nationalism and so on – emerged at that time. While industrialisation, economic growth and imperialism led to technological advances and levels of prosperity the likes of which the world had not seen before, they also caused social and environmental disruption on a global scale. Wars caused destruction on an unprecedented scale, social bonds that had defined the fabric of society for centuries were broken and even the biosphere was affected. In the context of seeking solutions to such problems, reference was repeatedly made to the state and, increasingly, also to the need for cooperation between states. The development of this thinking since the eighteenth century is the subject of this course.
  Leerdoelen The purpose of this course is to study themes that are covered elsewhere in the bachelor’s degree programme in greater depth. Students will be introduced to historical thinkers and their theories regarding the state and the relationship between state and society. Students will develop the ability to place these thinkers and their works in their respective contexts. Students will read primary texts/sources. Students will learn how to independently initiate and structure a meaningful discussion.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. SPI Huls', 'JAM Bom', 'MMJ Galekop', 'SS Bour']
text:
Inhoud Na het afronden van de Honours Class kan je zelfstandig richting geven aan jouw eigen persoonlijke ontwikkeling en hierop reflecteren.

Om dat te bereiken kun je: 
  • Leerdoelen opstellen die in lijn zijn met je kernwaarden;
  • Een planning maken waarin je specificeert en beargumenteert welke stappen je onderneemt om je doelen te bereiken, in welke volgorde je dat doet, en welke hulpbronnen je daarbij nodig hebt;
  • Reflecteren op je eigen vooruitgang, zowel wat betreft het maken van producten als het aanleren van vaardigheden;
  • Medestudenten op correcte wijze feedback geven en constructief omgaan met feedback die je van medestudenten krijgt;
  • Een aantrekkelijke presentatie geven aan medestudenten over een studie-gerelateerd onderwerp;
  • Je zelfstandig verdiepen in de onderzoeks-, beleids- en managementaspecten van een zorggerelateerd onderwerp en hier verslag van doen;
  • Een inhoudelijke bijeenkomst organiseren over een zorg-gerelateerd onderwerp.
Leerdoelen De Honours Class is er voor studenten die gemotiveerd zijn om naast de reguliere vakken een verdiepend studieprogramma te volgen.

Je kiest aan het begin van de Honours Class het zorg-gerelateerde onderwerp waar je tijdens de rest van de Honours Class aan werkt. Vervolgens specificeer je leerdoelen – wat wil je over dit onderwerp leren? – en maak je een plan hoe je die doelen gaat bereiken en hoe je door middel van door jou zelf gespecificeerde producten gaat bewijzen dat je de doelen behaald hebt. Uit je leerdoelen en je plan blijkt dat je aandacht hebt voor kennis én voor vaardigheden. Je producten maak je voor jezelf maar ook voor anderen waar je in je studie mee te maken krijgt: van je producten is er minstens een die interessant is voor een onderzoeker, een voor een beleidsmaker en een voor een manager.

lecturers: ['dr. NR Matawlie', 'LWD Wijtvliet']
text:
Inhoud

The Honours Class Private Equity is an extra-curricular programme that can be followed in addition to the regular programme and tries to increase impact of education by training the application of theory.
In a challenging and demanding learning environment students come into contact with experts from the field in order to be able to directly test the knowledge gained in practice. The program consist of a series of guest lectures and a private equity game in block 2 and 3.
The ambitious extra-curricular program brings together a 24 selected Financial Economics students with an interest in investment in an inspiring and intensive study track.

Leerdoelen

Students know different types of acquisitions in private equity and how these are structured and financed.
Students know fundamental economic theories in corporate finance and and have insight into how these can be applied.
Students know strengths and weaknesses of the use of different types of valuation models and have insight into the context where these can be applied.
Students are able to form an opinion based on different perspectives acquisitions and private equity investment.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. C Dalla Chiesa', 'dr. EMMP Loots', 'dr. LE Braden']

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. M Slot', 'JB Zomerplaag']
text:
Inhoud This course is open—by invitation only—to IBCoM’s most talented and highly motivated students. Once they are invited to the course, interested students must submit a special application. A limited number of applicants can be accepted in the program.
 
CM2100 gives excellent students access to opportunities and challenges beyond the normal scope of an undergraduate program. Honours students are exposed to the most recent developments in communication and media studies. Moreover,  various and attractive fieldtrips, as well as close contact with professionals, organizations and experts give students the opportunity to witness and, in many cases, actively engage in real life communicative and media practices within public and private institutions. Students’ own contribution in the HP’s curriculum—through engagement in class discussions, presentation of their own work, building of a portfolio and the organization of the honours symposium —further enables them to actively explore new areas of interest.
 
The course is organized in two modules, and an honours symposium at the end.
 
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • The state of the art in specific areas of communication and media studies beyond the normal scope of the undergraduate curriculum.
  • The perspectives of professionals and experts working in media and communication-related industries and organizations.
Students are able to:
  • Actively explore new areas of interests and participate in the proposal, organization, and preparation of seminar sessions.
  • Further their reading, research, writing, and presentation skills.
  • Work independently on a research project and publicly report their results.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['A. Oudijn', 'dr. G. Jansen', 'dr. J.W. van Neck', 'dr. M.J. Koudstaal']

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['E van der Wal, MSc', 'prof.dr. AACM Smeets']
text:
Inhoud

In deze minor zul je kennismaken met een aantal belangrijke inzichten uit de Psychologie.

De psychologie is een wetenschappelijke discipline die probeert het gedrag, de gedachten, gevoelens en drijfveren van mensen te begrijpen, te verklaren en te voorspellen. Na deze minor Hoogtepunten uit de psychologie zul je beter begrijpen waarom mensen doen wat ze doen. Meer begrip van menselijk gedrag kan buitengewoon relevant zijn voor alle disciplines waar mensen de hoofdrol spelen. Denk bijvoorbeeld aan de economie, de rechtspraak, de bedrijfskunde, de politicologie, maar ook in de bouwkunde of de ICT. We hopen dat de kennis die je in deze minor op doet van toegevoegde waarde is voor je huidige studie. Maar we hopen vooral dat je door meer kennis van de psychologie ook meer kennis van jezelf krijgt.

De psychologie is een enorm vakgebied. Natuurlijk kunnen we in het tijdsbestek van één minor niet alle belangrijke psychologische inzichten de revue laten passeren. Daarom hebben we een selectie gemaakt van een aantal van de meest tot de verbeelding sprekende theorieën en ontdekkingen. Deze komen onder andere voort uit de sociale psychologie, de persoonlijkheidsleer, de biologische psychologie en de klinische psychologie.

De minor wordt in het Nederlands aangeboden, maar de literatuur is Engelstalig.

Er wordt gewerkt in kleine teams. Studenten zijn van elkaars input en bijdragen afhankelijk. Daarom is aanwezigheid en actieve deelname verplicht.

Gedurende de wekelijkse bijeenkomsten krijgt de student feedback van de tutor. Dit kan betrekking hebben op studievoortgang en werkhouding en persoonlijke ontwikkeling (professioneel gedrag). 

Afsluitende kennistoets (multiple choice) of verslag.

Leerdoelen
Na afronding van deze minor heeft de student basale kennis van een aantal belangrijke psychologische theorieën uit de volgende subdisciplines:
  • De sociale psychologie
  • Persoonlijkheidsleer
  • Ontwikkelingspsychologie
  • Klinische psychologie

Verder maakt de student kennis met verschillende vormen van psychologisch (wetenschappelijk) onderzoek.

Door de werkvorm van Probleem Gestuurd Onderwijs (PGO) leert de student:

  • In kleine groepen met studenten uit verschillende disciplines psychologische problemen te analyseren
  • Uit deze probleemanalyse relevante (persoonlijke) leerdoelen te formuleren
  • Nieuwe inzichten en kennis terug te koppelen in een multidisciplinair team
  • Te reflecteren op zijn/haar eigen functioneren
De minor probeert de student aan te zetten om op basis van psychologische theorieën te reflecteren op zijn/haar persoonlijke en professionele ontwikkeling.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. TEM Paaso']
text:
Inhoud

Course overview:

In this course, students will look at financial decision-making from the perspective of households and individuals. With rising levels of debt and strained pension systems, there is a need to understand the financial decisions facing households and the way in which firms and policymakers can address these. The course also aims to provide insight into new areas of finance such as fintech which provide new challenges for regulators and opportunities for consumers.

The course aims to provide a framework that students can use to think about financial decision-making as well as apply this knowledge to socially relevant challenges, such as overindebtedness among economically vulnerable groups. In addition, the course investigates the importance of access to finance around the world and provides some examples of how companies (such as fintechs) are addressing consumer needs in new ways.

Leerdoelen

Learning goals

After the course,

  • Students will be able to develop a framework for thinking about household financial decision-making
  • Students will understand the role of financial products in improving consumer welfare and the financial instruments available to individuals and households
  • Students will be able to use this framework to debate the merits of extending access to financial services (financial inclusion) as well regulation of financial services
  • Students will be able to propose solutions on using technology to help providers of financial products improve consumer well-being
  • Students will better understand the role of access to finance in improving (and worsening) consumer welfare

course_title: Huid, bot en weke delen tumoren

lecturers: ['dr. KA Sikora']
text:
Inhoud We humans have an irresistible urge to explain our own and others’ behaviour, to attribute it to some causes and therefore, to make it seems orderly, predictable and controllable. Why do we behave, think, and feel as we do in social situations? How are our thoughts, feelings and behaviours shaped by others? How do we make sense of our social world and how do we become social? How do we see ourselves? These are the type of questions that the course Man & Society seeks to address. Obviously, a huge number of variables play a role in answering these questions and many disciplines employ scientific techniques to answer these questions. However, in this course we will try to answer these questions from a socio-psychological perspective and use quantitative research to investigate how and why certain (socio-psychological) behaviours occurred.

Open to exchange students: no
Leerdoelen This course deals with an important and relevant area of psychology, the social psychology. Social psychology is the scientific field that seeks to understand the nature and causes of individual behaviour in social situations. Social psychologists are interested in underlying social and cognitive processes as they are in overt behaviour. The central theme of social psychology is how people understand and interact with each other.
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:
  • Discuss the history and research methods of social psychology;
  • Distinguish between cultures regarding the processes that underlie our thought, behaviour, and feelings in social situations;
  • Apply theoretical concepts of this course in a more practical manner;
  • Identify the components of the self and self-schemas;
  • Define attitudes and how they develop and change;
  • Compare the different routes of persuasion;
  • Explain the theories and dynamics of group formation: social categorization and social identity;
  • Understand the antecedents and consequences of stereotyping, prejudice, racism, discrimination, and genocide;
  • Define aggression and its associated theories;
  • Describe evolutionary approaches to helping others and the bystander effect;
  • Understand the way people attach meaning to other’s and their own behavior;
  • Explain the theories of attraction and romantic relationships;
  • Write a scientifically sound research paper on a particular subtopic from social psychology.

Inhoud
The study of anatomy (and morphology) is crucial in understanding how multiple tissue types and organ systems are organised in multicellular organisms, and how they interact. Moreover, it is not possible to understand how such organisms ‘work’ (as studied in physiology) without having fundamental anatomical knowledge. Clearly, this knowledge is also vital when studying the nature of a disease (pathology) as well as the biological mechanisms that lead to disease (pathogenesis).
In this course, we will focus on the anatomy of humans. You will learn the exact location, three-dimensional orientation and morphology of all major human body parts, and you will learn the correct anatomical language that is required to describe these parts. Particular attention will be given to the cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, nervous, and musculoskeletal systems. The course is designed in tight collaboration with the Erasmus MC, and consists of expert lectures, interactive tutorials, and dissection room practicals, which ensure that you will get a practical, hands-on learning experience.

  Leerdoelen
In this course, you will:
  • obtain a general understanding of the use and importance of general anatomical nomenclature (in Latin and/or English);
  • learn to actively use the terms in the anatomy checklist to describe the basic anatomy of the bony skeleton and its joints;
  • be able to relate the dermal and musculoskeletal system of the extremities to its nervous innervation;
  • be able to explain how musculoskeletal system allows the movement and stability of the human body;
  • be able to identify and describe the basic anatomy and functional properties of the anatomy of the thorax;
  • learn how to describe the main characteristics of the human blood circulation and name the main arteries and veins of the human body;
  • be able to identify and describe all the abdominal and pelvic organs and know where they are located in the abdominal and pelvic cavity, respectively;
  • learn the basic functional anatomy of the human nervous system and head and neck structures.

course_title: Human Behavior and Experiments in Development
lecturers: ['M Rieger']
['dr. JP Kloeg']
text:
Inhoud The first part of the course offers a systematic overview of the main subjects  and concepts of Philosophical Anthropology (such as the place of man in the Cosmos, the relationship between body and mind, consciousness, action, freedom of will, (inter)subjectivity, reflexivity and language), and its relationship to other philosophical disciplines, such as ethics and social philosophy, and the empirical sciences and humanities, which deal with human beings, such as biological anthropology, neuroscience, psychology, sociology, history, and cultural anthropology.
Next, we will distinguish the mechanistic, organismic, and hermeneutic conception of man and, inspired by Kant’s and Dilthey’s transcendental philosophy, we will analyze the third-person, second-person, and first person ontological perspectives connected to these conceptions. Against the background of the ‘Historization of the World View’, both in its naturalistic (Darwin) and hermeneutic (Dilthey) form, we will discuss Plessner’s philosophical anthropology as a still topical attempt to connect the two. Finally, against this background, will reflect on the possible futures of the human life form in the light of the so-called converging technologies (such as information technology, neuroscience, and biotechnology). Leerdoelen

The seminars are not obligatory.

The lectures will be recorded.

At the end of this course the student understands and can use the key concepts of philosophical anthropology, is able to distinguish the differences between mechanistic, organismic, and hermeneutic approaches in the study of human nature, and has acquired a basic knowledge of the history and the possible futures of the human life from an evolutionary (Darwin), historical (Dilthey), and philosophical-anthropological (Plessner) perspective.

lecturers: ['dr. AW Prins']
text:
Inhoud
In this second part of ‘Human Conditions’ we will focus on Phenomenological & Hermeneutical approaches. Our point of departure will be the fortuitousness of western philosophy and the unsolved, but ever tentalising question, how we may comprehend the phenomenon of human existence while simultaniously being 'subject' and 'object' of this attempt toward comprehension ourselves.
Key figures in this course will be: Kierkegaard (on truth and individual existence), Husserl (on transcendental subjectivity as the ‘wonder of all wonders’), Heidegger (on the 'event' of being human and the framing of existence in the era of Technology), Sartre (the ontology of absolute freedom and radical responsibility), Merleau-Ponty (on the phenomenology of bodily perception), Gadamer (on philosophical hermeneutics) and Levinas (on questioning the primacy of ontology in phenomenology and western philosophy as a whole).
Leerdoelen

The seminars are not obligatory.

Lectures will be recorded.

1. Understanding the historical predicaments of the ‘first-person perspective’ in Western Philosophy
2. Acquaintance with the main currents in the Phenomenological Movement and the ‘turn’ from Phenomenology to Hermeneutics
3. The ability to assess the importance, relevance and limitations of the philosophical positions presented and discussed during the course, and taking well-argued positions
4. Acknowledging the importance of, and being able to practice ‘stirring thinking’
5. The ability to thoroughly comprehend philosophical texts (academic skill training).

lecturers: ['FA Verheul']
text:
Inhoud Human physiology studies how cells, tissues, organs and organ systems function in a healthy human body in response to internal and environmental changes. As a central concept in physiology, this course will highlight homeostatic processes, i.e. the maintenance of the steady state of the body within regulated ranges that are compatible with life. You will learn that homeostasis is regulated at multiple levels, from the cellular all the way to the organismal level. In this course, we will study the components and function of different physiological systems in the human body, including the cardiovascular system, circulatory system, respiratory system, musculoskeletal system, digestive system, urinary system, and the endocrine system. The human physiology will mainly be discussed under normal conditions, although pathologies and exceptional circumstances will be mentioned, such as high-altitude and space physiology. Importantly, this course aims to provide an integrated view of human physiology, acknowledging the complex interactions within and between different physiological systems.

  Leerdoelen
The physiology of systems under scrutiny include the integumentary system, the nervous system, the circulatory system, the respiratory system, the musculoskeletal system, digestive system, renal system, and the endocrine system. The immune system will be studied in detail in Quad 4, 200-level course, 'Micro- and immunobiology', and is therefore not a focus within this course.
Learning objectives regarding the biological systems under study include:
  1. Be able to recognize different histological tissue samples from one another.
  2. Be able to describe the structure and identify characteristics of the organs’ tissues and relate them to their functioning.
  3. Know the normal vital physiological parameters.
  4. Understand how these vital parameters are regulated/ kept constant under normal and extraordinary circumstances (e.g., microgravity, high altitudes, cold temperatures).
  5. Be able to make and present a scientific poster in a clear and attractive way.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. A Burmeister', 'dr. CISG Lee', 'dr. ME Schouten', 'dr. RL Hewett']
text:
Inhoud In many industries, the people – or the Human Resources – are the vital factors shaping success or failure for organizations. Decisions that involve the hiring, training, job assignments, and retention (or dismissal!) of employees have far-reaching consequences. These consequences do not only involve financial gains, losses, or potential legal implications for the organization, but also affect individuals and their motivation and ability to be productive and satisfied.

This course offers you an evidence-based perspective on the main challenges in Human Resource Management (HRM). We begin by examining the conceptual foundations of HRM, including the design of jobs and work processes, and the conditions under which work is satisfying and engaging. We then focus on the hiring process all the way from human resource planning to sealing the deal with new hires and starting the socialisation process. Building on this, we deal with how one can achieve great results with the people within an organization by motivating and rewarding their efforts, measuring their performance, as well as training and developing them for current and future tasks. Finally, we will consider how to manage employees’ voluntary and involuntary exit from organizations.

By the end of the course, you will have a deep understanding of and basic hands-on experience with the most important HR practices in light of empirical evidence that supports or discourages their use.  You will have learned to look beyond short-term financial gains for the organization when making decisions that affect people in organizations, but also have a thorough understanding of evidence-based guidelines on employee well-being, job satisfaction, and fairness. As a result, you are able to use your knowledge and skills about HRM to be a force for positive change for peoples’ working lives.

Given that HRM is a central organizational function, this course has links to many other courses in your curriculum. It particularly builds on your first-year course Organisational Behaviour, which laid the foundation for many of the concepts we will apply to workplace settings in this course and sets the stage for the third year specialism for People Experts.
  Leerdoelen
Learning goals
After following this course, students will be able to:
  • Explain fundamental HRM practices and their theoretical underpinnings.
  • Design solutions for HR-problems and cases by integrating theoretical knowledge and practical considerations.
  • Apply HR-related knowledge and skills to solve real-world organizational challenges in an international context.
  • Develop an evidence-based mindset in reflecting on the role of evidence in guiding the actions of people managers.

course_title: Human Resource Management in de Publieke Sector: Capita Selecta
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['AL van Zijl, MSc', 'prof.dr. AJ Steijn', 'prof.dr. F Koster']
text:
Inhoud Human Resource Management (HRM) gaat er vanuit dat de mens een belangrijke bron is voor organisatiesucces en heeft daarom als doel het personeelsmanagement zo goed mogelijk te laten verlopen. Hoewel dit geldt voor HRM in alle organisaties, kent HRM in publieke organisaties een aantal specifieke uitdagingen en toepassingen.

In deze module wordt daarom ingegaan op actuele thema’s binnen HRM in de publieke sector zoals wendbaarheid, inclusiviteit, mobiliteit en werkgeluk. Deze thema’s hebben gemeenschappelijk dat ze hoog op de agenda van wetenschappers en beleidsmakers staan. In de hoorcolleges wordt dan ook gebruik gemaakt van actuele voorbeelden en recente literatuur.
 
De literatuur voor dit vak bestaat uit wetenschappelijke artikelen die via Canvas te verkrijgen zijn. Er wordt van u verwacht dat u voorafgaand aan het hoorcollege de aangewezen artikelen leest. Het is daarnaast mogelijk om voorafgaand aan ieder hoorcollege een individuele opdracht in te leveren. Door deze individuele opdrachten met een voldoende af te ronden kunt u 20% van het eindcijfer behalen, en hoeft u minder vragen te beantwoorden op het take-home tentamen.



  Leerdoelen •   Beschrijven welke overeenkomsten en verschillen er tussen HRM in publieke en private organisaties zijn;
•   Toelichten welke actuele en toekomstige thema’s er op het gebied van HRM in de publieke sector spelen;  
•   Beredeneren welke invloed HRM in een publieke organisatie heeft;
•   Uiteenzetten hoe HRM in de publieke sector kan worden toegepast.

course_title: Human Resource and Organizational Behaviour Analytics
text:
Inhoud
Instructors: Dr. Marc van de Wardt, Prof. Svetlana Khapova.

Course Description:
Most organizations today collect a wealth of data that could help improve organizational outcomes. Still, only few succeed in using this data successfully. The phenomenon of Human Resource (HR) Analytics and the respective field(s) of research could potentially fill this void. HR Analytics gained traction in recent years as a movement that could let the HR profession evolve. Contrasting with the "soft” approach that was long associated with the HR, HR Analytics seeks to add value to the organization by leveraging analytical processes, a broad range of statistical techniques, and novel data sources.

In this course, we learn how to use HR data and HR Analytics to improve business outcomes and make better HR decisions. The overarching question of the course is how can organizations use data to better understand organizational processes? Through a sequence of readings, lectures, and experiential exercises, we learn what questions to ask, how to determine which methods to use, we will discuss the strengths and weaknesses of different research designs, we will analyze several (applied) datasets during the lab sessions and we will discuss what organizations could learn from the results of these analyses. We will be studying the following six topics each covered by a specialist: recruitment & diversity, recruitment & personality, HRM practices & organizational outcomes, employability, gender and leadership and careers.
Leerdoelen Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
 
  • Knowledge and understanding: Understand how organizations can use HR data to assess personality, diversity, employability, leadership, employee turnover and the effect of HR practices on organizational outcomes. Understand and critically discuss the strengths and weaknesses of different research designs
  • Application of knowledge: Apply different analytic techniques to address questions at the core of HR.
  • Making judgement: Understand the implications of these analyses for organizational practices
  • Communication: Engage in critical in-class discussions on academic research articles. Provide practical recommendations from HR Analytics to practitioners.

lecturers: ['dr. M Stambulski']
text:
Inhoud This course addresses the various legal instruments and monitoring/enforcement mechanisms for the international protection of human rights, placing emphasis on the United Nations and its various organs, as well as regional organizations (with a main focus on the Council of Europe and its European Convention on Human Rights). An advanced course in human rights law, the course is organized as a capita selecta subject. Thematic foci include freedom of religion, freedom of expression, right to education, LGBT rights, and non-state actors & human rights.
The different instruments and protection mechanisms are explored in relation to contemporary debates regarding the concept, scope, development and – obstacles to the actual – enforcement of human rights. The course aims at enabling students to identify the relevant actors, instruments and monitoring/enforcement mechanisms for the international protection of human rights. Furthermore, students successfully completing this course will be able to analyse recent trends and developments in the context of that framework and critically assess different points of view in relation to the application and interpretation of human rights. Students will also train their analytical, writing and debating skills by participating in the compulsory Seminars. Leerdoelen The course is designed to provide an intensive and advanced study of international human rights law drawing on its main mechanisms and relevant instruments and addressing key contemporary challenges.
Accordingly, students successfully completing this course will be able to:
- Independently analyse and assess, in the context of broader public international law, human rights treaty law;
- Independently analyse and assess, in the context of broader public international law, legal problem statements pertaining to the implementation or enforcement of international human rights law;
- Develop ways, in cooperation with others, of addressing human rights problem statements with profound societal ramifications;
- Independently present, in both oral (viz., in the form of moot court pleadings) and written (viz., in the form of written memorials) form, the results of academic research as well as legal advice, both to other lawyers and to a non-legally trained audience.

lecturers: ['dr. JD Handmaker', 'mr.dr. DJE Misiedjan']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. A Burmeister', 'dr. CISG Lee', 'dr. RL Hewett']
text:
Inhoud

In de meeste sectoren is het effectief managen van personeel – Human Resource Management (HR/HRM) – een bepalende factor voor het succes of het falen van de organisatie. Beslissingen over werving, training, taakstelling, beloning en ontslag hebben namelijk verstrekkende gevolgen. Ze hebben niet alleen betrekking op het economisch welvaren van de organisatie of het juridisch kader, maar vooral ook op mensen en hun motivatie, welzijn en productiviteit.

Deze cursus biedt een evidence-based perspectief op de belangrijkste uitdagingen in Human Resource Management. We beginnen met het onderzoeken van de conceptuele basis van Human Resource Management, inclusief het ontwerp van banen en werkprocessen en de voorwaarden waaronder werk bevredigend en boeiend is. Vervolgens richten we ons op het wervingsproces, van de personeelsplanning tot het aannemen van nieuwe medewerkers en het starten van het socialisatieproces. Hierop voortbouwend hoe we prestaties meten, hoe bedrijven goede resultaten kunnen bereiken door hun personeel te motiveren en te betalen voor hun inspanningen en hoe de opleiding en de ontwikkeling voor huidige en toekomstige taken vorm kan krijgen. Ten slotte gaan we na hoe we het vrijwillig en onvrijwillig verlaten van organisaties door werknemers kunnen beheren.

Het is de bedoeling dat je aan het eind van dit vak theoretisch inzicht hebt verworven in de belangrijkste HRM-praktijken en ze tegelijk ook op hun praktijkwaarde kunt beoordelen. Je zult leren om verder te kijken dan financieel gewin voor de organisatie op korte termijn, bij het maken van beslissingen die van invloed zijn op de mensen in de organisatie. Ook doe je een grondig begrip op, van de evidence-based richtlijnen omtrent welzijn van medewerkers, baantevredenheid en eerlijkheid. Daardoor zal je je kennis en vaardigheden in HRM kunnen toepassen om positieve verandering te bewerkstelligen in het werkleven van mensen om je heen.

Omdat HRM een centrale functie binnen organisaties heeft, is het vanzelfsprekend dat je verbanden zal kunnen leggen met andere vakken in het curriculum. We denken daarbij in de eerste plaats aan het vak Gedrag in Organisaties dat de basis legt voor dit vak wat betreft de concepten en theorieën die essentieel zijn om effectief functioneren binnen organisaties te begrijpen. In dit vak diepen we dit verder uit en leggen we de basis voor de specialisatie Behavioural Experts in het derde jaar.

Leerdoelen Leerdoelen
Nadat je dit vak succesvol hebt afgerond, ben je in staat om:
  • Fundamentele bedrijfsvoering binnen HRM en de theoretische grondslagen daarvan te beschrijven en begrijpen.
  • Theoretische kennis en praktische bedrijfskundige overwegingen samen te brengen voor het analyseren aanreiken van oplossingen voor HR-casuïstiek.
  • HR-gerelateerde kennis en vaardigheden toe te passen om problemen op te lossen binnen de internationale context waarin organisaties opereren.
  • Op de rol van wetenschappelijk bewijs als basis van HR-management te reflecteren.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. JR Sweeney']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
There is a growing need for advanced information processes, which simultaneously address individual and societal requirements. For example, by integrating sources of personal information within personalized health services to provide targeted self-care guidance, and improve healthcare system efficiency. This is needed because complex, and rapidly growing, societal problems such as obesity, diabetes, infectious disease transmission, and harmful drug use cannot be solved by broad institutional measures alone. Broad population-level policies are slow to adapt, are disproportionate, and do not lead to lasting change.

This course seeks new ways to address complex behavioral problems by putting human needs at the center of information process development. Students will learn about digital technologies which may be used to ingest personal information and facilitate targeted behavioral interventions ant individual and societal levels. For example, technologies such as wearable biometric devices, environmental sensors, different forms of social media, machine learning / artificial intelligence, natural language processing, digital diagnostics, genomics, computer vision, drones, edge computing, digital twins, mobility pattern analysis, process analysis, process automation, and targeted messaging systems may all be combined to collect various forms of individual information, calculate personal risk exposures, and deliver targeted behavioral interventions.

Students will design human-centered processes by applying behavior change and social ecological theories together with business process modeling techniques. Within an iterative process, students will actively participate in class discussions, present their work, and receive feedback for improvement. Throughout the course, we will review relevant academic, and industrial, projects as inspirational case studies. Class participation is mandatory. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
  • Understand technologies and methods which may facilitate human-centered processes
  • Identify a complex behavioral problem and develop suitable interventions through the use of one or more digital technologies
  • Recognize and include the role of the contextual environment in developing interventions
  • Apply business process modeling techniques as a standard language to convey your project ideas
  • Evaluate existing approaches and propose an improved process to guide individual and societal behavior

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. O Nyirubugara']
text:
Inhoud The first two decades of the 21st century have witnessed a considerable reduction of poverty and associated phenomena in countries previously labeled as “under-developed” countries. The rapid and widespread innovations, mostly enabled and  driven  by  Information  and  Communication Technologies (ICTs), have given rise to “Emerging Markets”, also known as “Emerging Economies”. More and more developing countries are making remarkable inroads into economic growth and some have even become global leaders in specific areas. The introduction of the Internet, followed by the advent of mobile telephony, has been instrumental in driving innovation in vital sectors such as education, healthcare, economic livelihood, and local entrepreneurship, to mention a few areas. ICT and Innovation scholars project not only more ICT-driven innovations in emerging markets, but also the transfer from those innovations into developed countries (reverse innovation).

This seminar offers students a critical, analytical, historical, and practical insight into the various ways in which Emerging Markets have been taking advantage of the development process to become central to the ICT-driven innovations. Students historically explores the transition from the previous approach, one that was mostly centred on international development policies, to the current home- grown, ICT-driven innovation approach to poverty alleviation. In this seminar, students get an insight into real-life ICT-driven innovations that involve various actors (e.g., local startups, NGOs, governments, multinationals) and in different areas and sectors. The seminar focuses on the following key areas: education (in the broader sense), healthcare, rural entrepreneurship (income- generating activities), economic livelihood, and banking (and related services). While exploring these areas, students are invited to go beyond the surface (the hype) to critically consider underlying concepts such as power, gender, sustainability, inclusiveness, and ethics.
  Leerdoelen

Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

* The range and usage of ICTs in communication for social development and profit
* The history and politics of ICT use in emerging economies
* The workings of real time based ICTD projects in emerging economies and the range of challenges with the market, the state and the public intersecting
 
Students have developed the skills to:

* Think strategically on real time public-private sector communicative approaches to contemporary issues involving ICT in education, politics, healthcare, and entrepreneurship
* Think critically on social and public policy
* Obtain information from/communicate with private sector professionals in the ICT4D (ICT for development) field in emerging markets

PR Klopf', 'dr. RL Olie', 'dr. TA Alade', 'dr. W Hulsink', 'dr. Y Liu', 'G Kim', 'prof.dr. G Liberali', 'prof.dr. LCPM Meijs', 'prof.dr. M van Rinsum', 'prof.dr. TH Reus', 'prof.dr. VJA van de Vrande', 'prof.dr. YM van Everdingen', 'prof.dr.ir. A Smidts']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The Research Clinic constitutes the formal start of the MSc International Management thesis semester. The seminar informs IM students about the following research issues: 
  • What makes good research compelling? 
  • How does one write an interesting and persuasive thesis? 
  • How does one formulate a challenging research question? 
  • What is an adequate research methodology to answer the central research question? 

Course information
Pre-requisites: Students must have completed the full first year of the MSc International Management/CEMS programme in order to advance to the research clinic and thesis semester.

Course structure: The Research Clinic is structured around four plenary lectures that address the research issues stated above; in parallel, students work in small-scale highly interactive work groups applying these themes to their own research topic. Groups will typically consist of students sharing similar research topics. The output of this seminar is a research proposal for the Master thesis.

All plenary sessions are interactive; students can expect to be asked questions, to make presentations, or to engage in discussion with other fellow students. The preceding implies that students are expected to come to class prepared, having carefully read all the compulsory literature and submitted the assignments.

In addition to the plenary sessions, students have three work-group sessions with their supervisor. These sessions focus on the actual writing of the research proposal. Depending on the supervisor these sessions will be run in groups or individually. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  • To enhance the student’s understanding of the process and methods of international business and management research.
  • To assist students in applying this knowledge and methodology to their own research project.

Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to:
  • understand what good research is
  • construct an interesting story and write a persuasive thesis (proposal)
  • craft an interesting and relevant research question
  • select an appropriate research methodology to answer a specific research question
  • construct and plan the design and execution of a study

lecturers: ['PAM Bardoel']

text:
Inhoud

Een ITP-TOEFL toets (Institutional Testing Program) is een variant van een TOEFL-toets waarvan de behaalde resultaten alleen geldig zijn binnen de Erasmus Universiteit. De uitslag van de toets kun je gebruiken om je taalniveau aan te tonen voor toelating tot een studie of een Engelstalig (uitwisselings)programma.

Belangrijk om te weten De ITP TOEFL toets word op de campus afgenomen. Data en tijden

De eerstvolgende ITP-TOEFL vindt plaats op:

  • Dinsdag 11 juli 14.00– 16.30 uur
  • Deadline 28 juni 2023
Locatie: campus Woudestein

lecturers: ['dr. P Wilinski', 'EW de Waegh, LL.M']
text:
Inhoud The Ian Fletcher International Insolvency Moot is the most prestigious moot competition in the field of international insolvency law in the world. Even though the competition is still relatively young (the first competition was organised in 2017), it has already gained a significant international reputation. In the words of the organisers:
“The Fletcher Moot encourages the best and brightest students around the globe to learn about international insolvency law and international commercial litigation. The competition is dedicated to raising the profile of insolvency and restructuring within the university curriculum.
Students will have a chance to engage with their peers, judges and members of international insolvency bodies. It also provides an avenue for academics, judges and a diverse range of insolvency experts to collaborate in mentoring the next generation of lawyers.
The Fletcher Moot is coordinated by Professor Adrian Walters (Chicago-Kent College of Law, red.), and Jelena Wenlock is the Moot Registrar.”
Last academic year, the competition attracted a record number of 28 registrations from law schools across the world. This is a similar number to comparable moot courts in a niche field of law, such as the International Maritime Law & Arbitration Moot, and the PAX Moot.
Comparable as well to other moot courts, the Fletcher Moot consists of two parts: written submissions for both claimant and respondent, followed by pleading sessions directly against other universities. The teams are evaluated on both these aspects separately. Previous winners of the written aspect of the competition include the National Law University (India), Leiden University, the University of Queensland (Australia), and the National University of Singapore. Previous winners of the oral pleadings include the University of British Columbia (Canada), Singapore Management University (twice), and the National Law University (India). 
The venue of the pleading sessions is different every year. The pleadings have been organised by the Queensland University of Technology in Sydney and in London, by the University pf British Columbia in Vancouver, and by Singapore Management University in Singapore. Both Leiden University and Radboud University have represented the Netherlands in previous editions of the Fletcher Moot.
A university team consists of two to maximum four students, and they may be supervised by a maximum of two coaches. Teams are evaluated in four categories: legal analysis, research, argument, and style. Competing students must resolve the moot problem based on the Model Laws on Insolvency created by the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL). These are most notably the UNCITRAL Model Law on Cross-border Insolvency (1997) and the UNCITRAL Model Law on Enterprise Group Insolvency (2019). These instruments have been determinative in unifying the field of international insolvency across all continents and they are leading in the academic debate on this topic.
The competition is supported by the two largest international associations for insolvency practice: the III (International Insolvency Institute) and INSOL International (International Association of Restructuring, Insolvency & Bankruptcy Professionals).

Finally, the name giver of the competition, Professor Ian Fletcher, is internationally recognised for his outstanding achievements in the field of insolvency law. In 2013, he was the first academic to be awarded the highly prestigious INSOL Scroll of Honour. Sadly, Professor Fletcher passed away in 2018.

2021 Competition
Following government measures in the wake of the covid-19 pandemic, the entire 2021 competition will take place virtually.
The moot problem has already been released on 11 September 2020. Registrations for the competition close on 16 October. Subsequently, on 6 November the deadline for written submissions is scheduled. Teams are informed of their acceptance to the oral rounds in December. Finally, the oral rounds will take place in March 2021, with the grand final scheduled provisionally on 20 March 2021.

In conclusion, the Fletcher Moot is an exceptional opportunity for students, studying a Commercial Law or Private Law master, who want to deepen their knowledge on international insolvency law. At the same time, this competition uniquely prepares students for legal practice by simulating a real-case scenario. Especially in times of economic turmoil, like nowadays, educating excellent insolvency law practitioners is essential. Few better opportunities than the Ian Fletcher International Insolvency Moot exist to do so. Leerdoelen Familiarize students with international insolvency law procedures

course_title: Images & Power: Foundation of Media Studies
text: Inhoud Today’s culture is a visual culture. Since the 1970s, the social sciences and the humanities have increasingly turned their attention to the many ways in which visual technologies and images have come to play a central role in the construction of the shared meanings, or mental representations, through which our social practices are structured. Images reproduce power relations as much as they can contest dominant ways of seeing, and thinking about, the world. In this course we will analyse representations of class, gender, race and sexuality that circulate in the media by discussing and applying various key texts and methodologies from the fields of media studies and cultural analysis. Students read foundational texts by authors such as Roland Barthes, Stuart Hall, and Laura Mulvey and apply various visual methodologies in order to analyse a self-selected set of images in our weekly workshop.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. JM Engelbert']
text:
Inhoud Different professions play an important role in shaping how cities are and can be imagined. Obvious examples are the creative and communicative work of popular culture producers, (travel) journalists or city marketeers. Their urban imaginations are more than mere re-presentations of cities and the people in it. In fact, they can carefully craft images or “brands”, which increasingly influence what kinds of capital, services, residents and tourists a city seeks to attract. The transformation of Rotterdam into a “brand destination” and a home for global mega-events and international capital exemplifies such strategic “imagineering”. However, not only creatives or communications professionals contribute to urban imaginations. Consider, for example, urban planners and engineers, whose designs, mock-ups and “digital twins” imagine life in the city as neatly manageable infrastructures. Or think of executives of digital economy platforms, like Uber or Airbnb. Their data systems model and value the city in terms of systems and flows that need constant optimizing.

This course explores this “business” of urban imaginations. It focuses on a wide range of professional practices and the way they feature and produce urban re-presentations, such as data, maps, travel guides, urban branding, image banks, digital twins, inter-city rankings digital apps. The course equips students to analyse these urban representations as social constructions, which have real-life implications for how we think of the city, and, especially, of who we consider that city to be of and for. While cases, guest speakers, materials and literatures will take students to cities all over the world, they should be particularly interested in learning a lot (more) about the business of urban imaginations in Rotterdam. Leerdoelen After this course, students will be able to: 
  
- Identify and explain how the practices and routines of a wide range of professions (re-)produce urban imaginations.
 
- Understand and explain how urban imaginations feature as part of broader power struggles.

- Consider the (local) policy implications of specific urban imaginations.

Inhoud
Does increasing legal retirement age maintain individuals longer at work? Does development aid raise economic growth? Do changes in schooling laws improve health? The answer to any of these questions requires valid methods to evaluate the impact of different interventions.
The objective of this course is to provide students with a set of theoretical and practical skills that will allow them to evaluate the causal impact of different policy interventions and social programs. The course will introduce students to a variety of econometric methods in impact evaluation and a set of reasoning skills to help them design an evaluation study and assess critically existing studies. Students will get hands‑on experience with applying the techniques in Stata.
At the end of the course students will be able to:
  • Understand and apply a variety of impact evaluation methods
  • Critically analyse impact evaluation research
  • Draw policy implications from impact evaluation research
Leerdoelen At the end of the course students will be able to:
  • Understand and apply a variety of impact evaluation methods
  • Critically analyse impact evaluation research
  • Draw policy implications from impact evaluation research

lecturers: ['prof.dr. JLW van Kippersluis']
text:
Inhoud

Does a university degree raise your future wage? Does increasing the legal retirement age maintain individuals longer at work? Does restricting the bonuses of portfolio managers lead to less risk taking? Does development aid raise economic growth? Answering such questions requires a valid method of evaluating the effect of interventions.
In medicine one patient group is randomly assigned to a treatment while others receive a placebo. Identifying the effect of treatment is then relatively straightforward. In business, economics and social policy, such randomized experiments are often infeasible, unaffordable or considered unethical. Statistical methods must then be used to estimate the effect of an intervention relative to a counterfactual. This often calls for a great deal of creativity on the part of the analyst.
This course will give a non-technical overview of the intuition behind the most frequently applied evaluation methods in economics. The students will learn the required steps in a valid evaluation, the distinction between correlation and causal effects, the assumptions of different methods and in which situation each method can be used.
The main concepts are introduced in the first five weeks. The second part of the course is devoted to a group assignment, which will consist of a critical assessment of an existing evaluation, providing suggestions for improvement, and implementing these suggestions yourself. The students will hand-in a written report.

Leerdoelen
  • Describe the difference between a correlation and a causal effect using the Potential Outcomes Framework.
  • Critically assess an existing policy evaluation/academic paper that aims to estimate causal effects.
  • Determine which Impact Evaluation method is best suited to study a research question.
  • Estimate causal effects using statistical software for the most often applied Impact Evaluation techniques (multiple regression, matching, fixed effects, difference-in-difference, instrumental variables, regression discontinuity).
  • Work in a team to successfully complete a group assignment.
Extra
  • Participation in the exam is only allowed for those that have handed in their assignment.
  • At least 5 out of 10 on the exam is required.

course_title: Impact Space: your first steps into making positive societal impact
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['AJ Bok', 'DHB van Vliet, MSc', 'dr. G Binetti', 'drs. L Ligtendag', 'L Litjens', 'MI Sanchez Cecilia, MSc', 'MT de Ruiter', 'S Zijlstra', 'T Nobbe']
text:
Inhoud

In the impact space you will embark on an experiential journey, fueled by your curiosity to create positive societal impact. You do have the capacity to help change the world. You do! In the ‘Impact space’ you will discover what it is that you can contribute, what skills you have and what knowledge you have. But you will also discover what it is you still must learn to help people to solve societal problems. 

We will depart from a timely, relevant and complex concern or question that is experienced and expressed by people working within that context. Together with these stakeholders you will peel off various layers, conceptualizations and understandings associated with the concern. By exploring these different layers, you will get insights into the different (systemic) causes and get a better understanding of why we struggle breaking through patterns and solving complex problems. While you collect perspectives and worldviews to discover these deeper structures, you get introduced to methods to break the possible vicious cycles. By using these different (design)-methods, such as co-creation, transdisciplinary and futures thinking, you will be able to come up with (partial) solutions, directions for problem-solving, or to shine a new light on the issues, to help the stakeholder move forward. You will therefore gain considerate impact skills you are able to apply in future real-life situations.  

By participating in the impact space, you will develop your agency in societal change, reflect on the different roles you can take in participatory action-research and work on real-time, relevant projects in- and outside Rotterdam. You will learn to navigate complexity in an authentic, inspiring, yet sometimes frustrating learning environment, and work together with students from different academic backgrounds, external stakeholders and motivated coaches.


Special aspects

The Impact Space is open to all faculties, TUDelft and University of Leiden. This so you can work together with students from different academic backgrounds. As you will work on real-time relevant societal challenges in- and outside of Rotterdam, we will also work from locations that are in the city. We will go outside of the universities ‘walls’ so you are able to experience the real complex world outside that you will also encounter when you graduate.  


Overview content per week

Start: Groups will be formed based on interest. An introduction to these challenges will be given by means of a stakeholder arena.  

Archeology and history: Extensive research into the origin of the challenge and stepping into the field of stakeholders. In creative sessions you will practice system thinking and paradox thinking.  

Field research: Getting to know the stakeholders better and possibly rephrasing the challenge. Extensive reflection on one’s own (Erasmian) values and identity is incorporated to better understand others.  

Future: You dive into futures thinking by active and creative sessions. You are challenged to pick a solution direction and create a future scenario based on that direction. In this stage, you also contextualize their future scenarios from an academic point of view. 

Sharing and reflecting: What have you learned, what has the stakeholders learned. The insights of the groups are shared via a facilitated discussion with stakeholders and peers by the student groups themselves. Besides that, you will reflect on the impact of your findings. What did you learn from it? What contributes to collective learning processes? What is still missing? 


Teaching methods

The impact space is based on experiential learning. This means you focus on your learning process through application, observation and reflection. You will work in a self-regulated manner on the group-projects and receive structured coaching sessions. You document your process in portfolio assignments and share this with your coaches. The coaching sessions and portfolio form the basis for formative assessment. Everyone participates in (weekly) workshops and inspiration sessions that foster your knowledge and skills development on for example interdisciplinary collaboration and methods for co-creation and design.

Leerdoelen

The learning goals are: 

  • You are able to identify your own perspective and disciplinary knowledge(s) on complex issues and recognize that this individual perspective is, by definition, limited. 
  • You are able to identify your personal learning needs and interests and can reflectively evaluate your own learning process, for example at the cognitive, individual, relational and societal level and make connections between these. 
  • You develop considered and critical views, a curious mindset and value the perspectives and actions of others and incorporate these into your thinking and conceptualizations. 
  • You are able to facilitate collaborative and participatory research with stakeholders and are able to collaborate and communicate effectively with people who have diverse (national, cultural, disciplinary) backgrounds.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
