lecturers: ['mr. S Salverda', 'mr.dr.drs. L Postma', 'prof.mr. PAM Verrest']
text:
Inhoud De afgelopen jaren is het internationaal strafrecht zowel in omvang als betekenis toegenomen. Dit is grotendeels het gevolg van de ‘globalisering’ en daarmee ook van het (straf)recht. Er zal worden ingegaan op de traditionele instrumenten van het internationaal strafrecht: rechtsmacht, de uitlevering, de overdracht en overname van strafvervolging, de overdracht en tenuitvoerlegging van strafvonnissen en de kleine rechtshulp in strafzaken (politiële en justitiële rechtshulp). Daarnaast zal bijzondere aandacht worden geschonken aan het internationale strafrecht binnen de Europese Unie door middel van het Europees Arrestatiebevel en het Europees Onderzoeksbevel alsmede aan overige ontwikkelingen in de Europese rechtsruimte. Tevens zullen ontwikkelingen in de strafrechtelijke afdoening van internationale misdrijven worden besproken.
  Leerdoelen Het verschaffen en vergroten van inzicht in de manieren waarop landen met elkaar samenwerken bij de toepassing van strafrecht. Daarbij wordt tevens kennis van basisstructuren van strafrechtsplegingen in Europa bevorderd.

lecturers: ['prof.dr. FJM De Ly']
text:
Inhoud Ondernemen is voor de Nederlandse praktijk bijna in wezen grensoverschrijdend. In dit vak wordt deze internationale dimensie voor het voetlicht gebracht. Is Boek 2 bijvoorbeeld altijd toepasselijk in grensoverschrijdende gevallen? Is de Nederlandse rechter wel bevoegd voor grensoverschrijdende gevallen van massaschade? Worden contracten altijd beheerst door Nederlands recht? Wanneer kunnen internationale geschillen door arbitrage beslecht worden? Wat is de rol van EU recht bij de oplossing van deze problemen? Wat is de functie van eenvormig privaatrecht (bijv. EU Richtlijnen, Weens Koopverdrag) bij grensoverschrijdende gevallen?
Het Internationaal privaatrecht omvat daarbij het samenstel van regels die privaatrechtelijke rechtsverhoudingen met internationale elementen bestrijken. Het gaat daarbij in het bijzonder om de vraag van het toepasselijke recht, de vraag naar de bevoegdheid van de rechter en of buitenlandse vonnissen in Nederland geëxecuteerd kunnen worden.
Tijdens het hoorcollege worden de algemene leerstukken en begrippen van het IPR besproken, zulks aan de hand van jurisprudentie en gevallen uit de praktijk. Door toepassing van de theorie op praktijkgevallen wordt tegelijkertijd inzicht verworven op het terrein van IPR-vragen bij zakenrecht, verbintenissenrecht, rechtspersonenrecht, burgerlijk procesrecht en arbitragerecht. De casuscolleges stellen de studenten in de gelegenheid enige vaardigheid te verwerven in het oplossen van casusposities op het terrein van het IPR aan de hand van de schriftelijke opgaven, die in de syllabus zijn afgedrukt. Leerdoelen Na afloop van dit vak kan de student:
  • De verschillende rechtsregels die behoren tot het IPR op nationaal, Europees en internationaal niveau toepassen op internationale commerciële geschillen.
  • IPR-uitspraken afkomstig van de Nederlandse rechter en het Europese Hof van Justitie kritisch becommentariëren en gebruiken bij het oplossen van internationale geschillen uit de praktijk.
  • De juridische methodologie van het internationaal privaatrecht begrijpen en de drie hoofdvragen uit het IPR onderscheiden en beantwoorden.
  • De diverse bronnen van het Nederlandse IPR en van internationale organisaties die zich inspannen voor harmonisering van IPR-regelgeving, raadplegen.
  • De werking van het IPR in de praktijk toelichten en het belang van regelgeving in het IPR aangeven.
  • Het IPR in bredere verbanden, zoals het Nederlandse IPR met het IPR van andere landen en het IPR in de context van de mondialisering van het recht, onderkennen en analyseren.

lecturers: ['prof.dr. FJM De Ly']
text:
Inhoud Door de toename van het internationale handels- en rechtsverkeer wordt het internationaal privaatrecht (IPR) steeds belangrijker. Het IPR omvat het samenstel van regels die privaatrechtelijke rechtsverhoudingen met internationale elementen bestrijken. Het gaat daarbij in het bijzonder om de vraag van het toepasselijke recht, de vraag naar de bevoegdheid van de rechter en de vraag naar grensoverschrijdende erkenning en tenuitvoerlegging van vonnissen. Welk recht is bijvoorbeeld van toepassing op een arbeidsovereenkomst tussen een Nederlandse werkgever en een in Frankrijk wonende werknemer? Welke rechter is bevoegd ten aanzien van een loonvordering van de werknemer tegen de werkgever? Kan een door de Franse rechter gewezen veroordelend vonnis in Nederland ten uitvoer worden gelegd? Op familierechtelijk terrein duiken gelijkaardige vragen op. Welk recht is bijvoorbeeld van toepassing op het huwelijksgoederenregime van een Belgische man die in 1989 in Frankrijk met een Nederlandse vrouw is gehuwd? En kan een door de Spaanse rechter uitgesproken echtscheiding in Nederland worden erkend?

Tijdens het hoorcollege wordt een aantal algemene leerstukken en begrippen van het IPR besproken aan de hand van jurisprudentie en gevallen uit de praktijk. Door toepassing van de theorie op praktijkgevallen wordt tegelijkertijd inzicht verworven op het terrein van IPR-vragen bij personenrecht, zakenrecht, erfrecht en huwelijksgoederenrecht, verbintenissenrecht, rechtspersonenrecht, insolventierecht en burgerlijk procesrecht.
  Leerdoelen De student is na afloop van dit vak in staat tot het:
 
  • analyseren, interpreteren en oplossen van casusposities op het gebied van het internationaal privaatrecht, in het bijzonder: (a) internationale arbitrage (b) onderneming- en insolventierechtelijke vraagstukken alsmede (d) internationaal personen-, familie- en erfrecht;
  • onderscheiden en beantwoorden van de drie hoofdvragen van het IPR (bevoegdheid, toepasselijk recht en erkenning en tenuitvoerlegging);
  • begrijpen van de juridische methodologie van het internationaal privaatrecht;
  • toepassen van de relevante nationale, Europese en internationale IPR-regels;
  • kritisch becommentariëren van IPR-uitspraken afkomstig van de Nederlandse rechter en het Europese Hof van Justitie en het gebruiken van deze uitspraken bij het oplossen van internationale geschillen uit de praktijk;
  • begrijpen hoe de werking van het IPR is in de praktijk;
  • begrijpen van het belang van regelgeving in het IPR;
  • duiden van actuele ontwikkelingen op het gebied van IPR-wetgeving en –rechtspraak;
  • onderkennen en analyseren van het IPR in bredere verbanden, zoals het Nederlandse IPR met het IPR van andere landen en het IPR in de context van de mondialisering van het recht.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['prof.dr. FRR Vermeylen']
text:
Inhoud
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" /><style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>The course will provide an in-depth discussion on international art markets, and will outline the way the art trade functions as an intermediary between artist and audience. Various aspects dealing with the production, distribution, consumption and valuation of different art forms will be discussed: price-setting mechanisms, segmentation of the art market, globalization of the art trade, the role of intermediaries and galleries, art as investment, etc. Special attention will be devoted to emerging art markets, and how they are impacting the international art market system. The seminars provide a guide to the subject matter and set out foundations on which students can build. The weekly class meetings depend on active participation by the students and provide the opportunity for in-depth discussion of key issues and optional topics from which the students can choose according to their own interests.</body>
</html>

Leerdoelen
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" /><style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>This course will confront master students with current research in the functioning of modern art markets. Students will be exposed to recent theoretical insights and research methods particularly drawing from the field of cultural economics. We will discuss relevant literature on the various subjects through lectures, student presentations and class discussion. Finally, the participants will focus on one topic and carry out individual research based on scholarly literature and (on-line) databases such as artprice.com, resulting in a final essay.</body>
</html>

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. AC Brown']
text:
Inhoud

The aim of the course is to introduce students to theories of international business as part of the Global Thinkers track and is the first of three interrelated courses. The course will cover topics relating with international business theory, ownership structure, IPOs, institutional investor, regulatory reforms, stakeholder involvement and corporate social responsibility. Some of the theory included are Agency theory; Transaction costs economics; Stakeholder theory; Stewardship theory; Institutional theory; Political theory as well as Network governance and case studies/ examples real life corporate stories.

The course will include lectures combining theory, cases and live examples including a project, for students to analyze, discuss and present on during seminar sessions and workshops. Students will be expected to be active participants in exploring real instances of effect of governance issues on actual entrepreneurial firms of all sizes but with particular attention to smaller and family enterprises. Students will be encouraged to make use of provided articles, case studies but also to explore themes and topics by accessing news sites, databases and public informational depositories in a guided but self-proactive environment.

Leerdoelen

After following this course, the student will be able to: Critically reflect on and provide well-grounded analysis of these elements crucial for small, medium firms, and Multinationals in developed and emerging markets as well as:

Knowledge and Understanding

  • Analyze the main elements of firm internationalization
  • Explore and understand key IB theories and their role in explaining/ understanding MNE formation
  • Evaluate the value of each theory in explaining firms’ internationalization
  • Critically appraise internationalization challenges for MNEs and firms in emerging markets
Skills
  • Cognitive/Subject-specific skills
    • Analysis, critical thinking, theory identification and use within context.
  • Construct expansion frameworks, considering alternatives and assessing these in light of recent academic insights
  • Evaluate business risks and opportunities for growth, reflecting on the potential for contributing to success as demonstrated by recent academic research.
  • Practical/subject specific skills
  • Synthesize information from appropriate sources
  • Demonstrate effective communication to persuade and influence stakeholders Key/transferable skills
  • Select and use appropriate investigative and research skills
  • Demonstrate effective report writing skills

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. GA Cross']
text:
Inhoud This course familiarizes you with the lanscape, culture and the business environment of the Netherlands: past, present and future. You will get to know different Dutch companies and organisations, each covering a different aspect of developing and doing international business in and from the Netherlands.
  Leerdoelen At the end of this course the student of the International Exchange is able to:
 
  • Understand how the landscape, in particular the relationship between water and land, has shaped Dutch culture and industrial development.
  • Understand Dutch company types, basic constructs and employer-employee relationships.
  • Understand, describe, analyse and compare the core business models of a number of Dutch companies and show how they address new business development through innovation.
  • Create and recommend proposals for how the Netherlands might thrive despite the impact of climate change (rising sea levels, sudden rainfall and warming).
  • Apply the power of diversity and team based cooperation within a group of different nationalities from all over the world.

Inhoud

Effective decision-making in an international business environment requires understanding the operation of different types of market economies and institutions of regional economic governance. This course is designed to provide you with an understanding of the institutional (or non-market) environment in which international businesses operate.

The course is divided in two parts. In the first part, we study business and politics in the European Union.  In particular, we analyse how ongoing debates (for example, on Brexit, the relationship with China, EMU, or the rise in populism) impact businesses in the European Union.  In the second part of the course we study the comparative political economy of ‘varieties of capitalism’. In particular, we examine the institutions and functioning of capitalist systems in coordinated, liberal and/or emerging market economies. Furthermore, we study the process of transition to a modern and open capitalist economy from a closed system.  Finally, we will be learning about thematic issues, such as intercultural management challenges or lobbying practices in a foreign environment.

Leerdoelen At the end of the course students will be able to:
  • to develop an understanding about how the world of (international) politics and business are intertwined
  • to analyze differences in rules of the game in different types of market economies
  • to assess different paths to and constraints on implementing market reforms
  • to understand the multilevel governance structure of the European Union and its impact on
  • the business environment in Europe
  • to understand the dynamics of management across cultures

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. MH Benischke']
text:
Inhoud

Course overview 

In this course, students will explore the interface between multilateral institutions, non-government actors, and the private sector, with a focus on the World Trade Organization (WTO). Global trade hit a record high of $28.5 trillion in 2021. Most of trade flows occur between WTO members, meaning that the activities of most if not all private sector actors are regulated by agreements signed by WTO member states. However, in contrast to the role of national formal (e.g., national rules and regulations) and informal (e.g., culture) institutions, the business relevance of such multilateral institutions is often insufficiently understood by future leaders.

The International Business Landscape course is designed to address this knowledge gap. The objective of this course is to broaden students’ understanding of multilateral institutions with a focus on the WTO, global trade policies, and their impacts on businesses. Special emphasis is laid on advancing students understanding regarding how special interests (e.g., private sector and civil society) influence international and national regulatory frameworks. Moreover, the course seeks to advance students appreciation for the complexity of ‘doing international business’ in a ‘rule-based’ global economy.

In terms of teaching, the emphasis of this course is on experiential learning. To that end, the course includes a two-day roleplay, whereby students will negotiate an international framework for global trade. In line with RSM’s mission, the focus of the roleplay will be on negotiating an international regulatory framework that aligns the WTO with global efforts to mitigate and adapt to climate change. For example, students will negotiate on issues such as tariff and non-tariff barriers for climate-friendly technologies.

Leerdoelen

Learning Goals 

After following this course, the student is able to:

  • Explain the challenges to develop international frameworks that are designed to address society’s grand challenges, most notably climate change.
  • Formulate a negotiation strategy for trade negotiations.
  • Apply negotiation skills in an international negotiation setting.
  • Apply public speaking skills in an international setting.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['AF Heslinga', 'dr. V Baptist', 'prof.dr. B Wubs']
text:
Inhoud   Multinationals and their role in the process of globalization have attracted a great deal of attention from business historians. The origins of modern multinationals, and consequently foreign direct investment (FDI), lay in the second half of the nineteenth century, although the Dutch East India Company (VOC), set up in 1602, is often considered to be the first multinational. However, the    growth of large scale, mainly industrial multinationals, concurred with the emergence of the first   liberal global economy. Trade protectionism, which represented a partial departure from liberalism, served to stimulate multinational manufacturing as well, because companies opened factories in protected markets. World War I was a turning point in the development of a global economy and the end of free trade. Yet multinationals continued to operate and even expanded during the 1920s and 1930s. After World War II multinationals began to play a key role in the world economy. As multinationals by definition operate in at least two different nations they necessarily have to deal with two different governments. Because of this interaction, there may be conflict or cooperation between multinationals and host and home governments. This course focuses on the ever-changing relations between multinationals and national governments from the late 19th century to the present. Leerdoelen
  • Explain the evolution of international business from 1500 to the present.
  • Describe the differences between multinationals and local companies.
  • Discuss, orally and on paper, the changing relations between international business and nation-states.
  • Differentiate between different types of international business and their corresponding period.
  • Explain the evolution of the balance between markets, companies, and networks.
  • Infer to what extent international business plays a role in international relations.

course_title: International Business from a Societal Perspective
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. P Versari', 'dr. PR van der Straaten']
text:
Inhoud

International business takes place in a broader societal context with local and global stakeholders who demand responsible business conduct wherever firms operate. In addition, calls have recently become louder for internationally operating firms to take on grand challenges (such as the UN Sustainable Development Goals) and play their part in making the world more equal, as well as environmentally and socially more sustainable. This course unfolds the societal and environmental dimensions of international business, offering students tools to conceptualize and manage the complex set of relationships between firms, their stakeholders, and society at large.   

Leerdoelen
  • Understanding the ethical dilemmas faced by international firms’ activities.
  • Identifying/foreseeing positive and negative social and environmental consequences of international firms’ activities.
  • Recognizing and engaging the most relevant stakeholders in projects aiming at improving the social and environmental impact of international firms.

lecturers: ['dr. P Wilinski', 'JP Valdivia Pizarro', 'prof.mr. GJ Meijer']
text:
Inhoud The course will discuss the arbitral process starting from the agreement to arbitrate to the challenge and enforcement of arbitral awards.

Students taking this class will already have a clear understanding and sufficient command of the fundamental concepts of arbitration law. Therefore, the course will build upon that knowledge and cover both the procedural aspects of the arbitral process and the study of the relevant applicable laws and regulations. During this course, the main concepts of arbitration law and the different procedural steps in an arbitration proceeding (e.g. commencing the arbitration, constitution of the tribunal, request for interim measures, taking of evidence, evidentiary hearing, making of the award, cost allocation, etc.) will be analyzed in detail and from a comparative law perspective. The most important instruments that come into play during an international arbitral proceeding will be studied in depth. Different applicable laws, conventions and regulations (e.g. UNCITRAL Model Law, the New York Convention, IBA Guidelines on Conflicts of Interest, IBA Rules on the Taking of Evidence, etc.) and different arbitration rules (such as the UNCITRAL, ICC and NAI arbitration rules) will be studied, with an emphasis on a comparative and critical analysis of the relevant instruments.

During the course, students will examine and compare different approaches seen in different jurisdictions, and/or provided by different institutions, in relation to similar issues and procedures in international arbitration (e.g. commencement of arbitration proceedings, appointment of and challenges to arbitrators, interim measures and emergency arbitration procedures, the conduct of the proceedings, annulment of arbitral awards, etc.).

Students will be encouraged and expected to actively participate and provide input and analysis based on the regulation of, and approach to, different issues and concepts in their own home jurisdictions.  Leerdoelen Familiarize students with and give them in-depth knowledge of arbitration law and practice from an international and comparative law perspective. After the course, the students will be able to:
  • Critically assess the different concepts in international arbitration.
  • Compare and understand the differences between, and the pros and cons of, the various instruments widely used in international arbitration (e.g., different institutional rules, different arbitration acts).
  • Understand the practical side of, and the relevant considerations when running, an international arbitration proceeding.
  • Understand and critically assess the relevant recent case law and latest developments in international arbitration.
  • Understand how an arbitral proceeding is run and what a young arbitration practitioner should and should not do.
Provide well-founded advice in relation complex questions, both of theoretical and practical nature, in relation to international arbitration proceedings.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. SJ Opree']
text:
Inhoud International conference participation is mandatory for all students of the two-year Research Master programme SCMA. Students are expected to participate in a relevant international conference with takes place before 1 July of their second year.  Leerdoelen Conference participation is beneficial to (emerging) scholars, as it is a way to:
  • Articulate and discuss research ideas and/or findings
  • Receive feedback on research;
  • Inspire and to motivate (state-of-the-art knowledge and research);
  • Maintain and grow the network (e.g. opportunities for job opportunities or future collaborations on projects on publications);
  • Grow both professionally and personally (e.g. develop knowledge and skills, get out of the comfort zone);
  • Build the CV.
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of: 
  • The importance, benefits, and common procedures of international conferences
  • Relevant international associations, networks and conferences in their field of study  
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Identify suitable academic organisations and venues for developing their personal research interests and networks
  • Connect to and present their work to international peers and scholars in the field
  • To develop and deliver a concise presentation about a research project at an international conference 
  • Reflect on their own performance and the performance of peers

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. RL Olie']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. CHO Schmitt']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
This course teaches a general management perspective on financial decision making and provides participants with the skills and knowledge to increase the value of a corporation. The course should appeal to participants who want to work as finance executives within a corporation, consultants, investment bankers, private equity, or venture capital investors. The course is also suited for participants who simply want to extend their finance knowledge beyond the financial management courses.

The aim of this course is to teach participants the knowledge and skills that a manager needs for good investment, financing, and operating decisions. The first part reviews essential financial concepts. The second part teaches participants how to recognize and manage financial risks. The third part discusses international investment decisions. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
  1. Understand whether companies should (not) engage in risk management
  2. Apply economic theory to understand business news
  3. Implement financial tools to manage risks
  4. Identify and measure financial risk exposures
  5. Understand stakeholder conflicts in an emerging markets setup

lecturers: ['prof.mr.dr. MJ van Ginneken']
text:
Inhoud This course examines corporate governance practices from an international and multidisciplinary perspective. Corporate governance deals with the mechanisms through which control is exercised over corporate managers. How do suppliers of finance (i.e. shareholders) make sure that managers do the right thing and do not steal the capital or invest the capital in bad projects? During this course the main topics of corporate governance will be discussed. The focus is on legal aspects of corporate governance. Among the topics to be discussed are:
 
- The definition of corporate governance; the separation between ownership and control; Agency costs theory;
- The functioning of boards of directors; the role of outside directors and one tier and two tier boards;
- Fiduciary duties;
- Disclosure and transparency;
- The role of executive compensation and the market for corporate control (hostile takeovers);
- Shareholder rights, shareholder activism and shareholder litigation;
- Corporate governance codes; securities regulations; monitoring by state agencies;
- Comparative corporate governance: developments towards convergence especially between the US and the EU.
  Leerdoelen Upon completion of this course students will be able to:
  • Understand the significance of corporate governance issues
  • Understand the way corporate governance issues are regulated
  • Value the rights and responsibilities of both shareholders and the board of directors
  • Understand the significance of internal and external monitoring
  • Independently analyze and solve legal questions concerning international corporate governance, including questions concerning regulation, board structure, takeovers and remuneration
Work in a team in order to analyze critically on how the current legal framework, relevant to the fields of international corporate governance operates and evolves and to provide a well-reasoned opinion of his/her own

Inhoud
<html>
<head>
	<title></title>
	<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
	<style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
	</style>
</head>
<body>The International Criminal Law course will provide students with the necessary knowledge to analyse past and current situations of crisis in order to determine whether core international crimes have been committed and what are the different mechanisms to bring the responsible to justice. The course examines the historical and legal developments in the different fields of international public law that brought about the creation of the International Criminal Court (ICC) and the different international and hybrid mechanisms of criminal justice conceived afterwards. It will then focus on the ICC’s jurisdictional parameters and triggering proceedings to later analyse in detail, discussing real current and past cases before the ICC, the different judicial proceedings before the Court, from preliminary to trial, appeal, and reparations proceedings.</body>
</html>

lecturers: ['prof.dr. E Kantorowicz - Reznichenko']
text:
Inhoud The covered topics:
  • The concepts, objectives and history of international criminal law
  • Jurisdiction & procedure
  • Genocide
  • Crimes Against Humanity
  • War crimes
  • Crime of aggression
  • Modes of liability
  • Defences
The course outline will set out the chapters that provide relevant background information for particular topics. For each class, additional reading materials will be prescribed to introduce the students to the scholarly work on different topics and relevant case law.
Students should have in their possession the most recent version of the ICC Statute and ‘Elements of Crimes’ (on the basis of article 9 ICC statute) and have it handy during lectures and group work sessions, as well as during the exam.
A good source which includes the main ICL documents, including the above, is, Cryer, Robert, ed. International criminal law documents. Cambridge University Press, 2019.
In addition to the textbook, students may always resort to supplementary literature, for example
  • Douglas Guilfoyle, International Criminal Law, OUP 2016.
  • Stahn, Carsten. A critical introduction to international criminal law. Cambridge University Press, 2019.
  • Cassese & P. Gaeta, Cassese’s International Criminal Law (Oxford University Press, 3rd edition, 2013) or
  • W. Schabas, An Introduction to the International Criminal Court (New York, Cambridge University Press, 4th edition, 2011).
  • Kai Ambos, Treatise on International Criminal Law, 3 vols. (OUP 2013, 2014, 2016).
  • Triffterer, Otto. Commentary on the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court. Baden-Baden: Nomos (1999).
  • An interesting recent book presenting a different view on the International Criminal Justice is by Christine Schwöbel-Patel, Marketing Global Justice: The Political Economy of International Criminal Law, Cambridge Studies in International and Comparative Law, Series Number 151 (Cambridge University Press, 2021)
During the course, students are expected to familiarize themselves and make use of the following websites containing most of the case-law and international legal instruments which will be examined (freely available on the websites):
ICC / International Criminal Court
ICTY / International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia
MICT / United Nations Residual Mechanism for International Criminal Tribunals
ICTR / International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda
 
Leerdoelen
The course aims to introduce students to the field of international criminal law, its unique features; development; institutions and procedures. Within the framework of the regime of international criminal law various international criminal courts and tribunals have been established in order to assess individual criminal responsibility at the international level, including the International Criminal Court, International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia and the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda. Attention is paid to the jurisdiction and procedure of these international tribunals, as well as to the definition of the four core crimes, namely aggression, genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity, and the distinctive modes of liability.
After completing the course:
 
  1. The student will be able to independently describe, analyse and assess the essential principles governing international criminal law as well as the various bodies and procedures through which international criminal law is being institutionalized;
  2. The student will be able to independently apply the essential substantive and procedural principles of international criminal law to hypothetical cases and deliver well founded legal advice; and
  3. The student will be able to independently conduct academic research relevant to international criminal law and based on this, provide a well-reasoned opinion of his/her own.

Inhoud This course will examine international dispute settlement in more depth, and with emphasis on inter-state judicial institutions, such as the International Court of Justice, and state/on-state dispute settlement. The opening lectures will address themes such as the concept of “international dispute”, the obligation to resolve disputes peacefully, the matrix of available dispute settlement options and the role and specificity of judicial dispute settlement mechanisms. Subsequent lectures will be devoted to the norms of “international legal procedure” governing international tribunals, with a focus on the International Court of Justice. The remaining lectures will turn their attention to the examination of specific judicial institutions, cross-cutting issues such as the independence and selection of judges and arbitrators, the role of the current dispute settlement “architecture”. Specific institutions which will be discussed include ITLOS, the WTO DS system and other mixed dispute settlement bodies, such as ICSID.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['AF Heslinga', 'dr. ME Hay', 'J Beocanin', 'LN Remij, MA', 'prof.dr. B Wubs']
text:
Inhoud
Why are some rich, while others remain poor? How have international trade, states, institutions, and (human) capital flows affected economic growth? These are some of the key questions that economic history deals with. Since 1500 the world has seen a wide variety of economic developments, such as industrialization, imperialism and colonialism, waves of globalization and deglobalization, and the rise and fall of economic centers. Transportation and communication technologies have created a smaller world with a higher level of economic interdependence.
These developments have had profound impacts on the economic development of regions around the world. Apart from war and treaties, the field of international relations also includes this economic dimension through trade, investment and other monetary relations. This course focuses on international trade and the development of international monetary systems. Furthermore, economic policies have varied over time, ranging from mercantilist power politics to international economic collaboration and from free trade to protectionism. This course addresses the questions that underpin global economic history and introduces theories from the field of international relations, including Realism, Liberalism, Constructivism, English School, Marxism, and Neoliberal Institutionalism.
Leerdoelen
  • Apply the most important international relations theories (Realism, Liberalism, Constructivism, the English School, Marxism, and Neoliberal Institutionalism) to historical cases of international economic relations.              
  • Describe the economic development for the ten regions discussed in the handbook.
  • Differentiate at least three theories that explain the different economic development between rich and poor nations.
  • Explain three different international monetary systems and how these affected national economic policies.
  • Explain the advantages and disadvantages of using economic growth as a measure of prosperity and well-being.
  • Describe how periods of protectionism and free trade alternated throughout history.

Inhoud International economics deals with issues raised by the interactions between countries. It can be divided into two broad fields: international trade and open-economy macroeconomics. The first deals with the real side of international economic relations, i.e. the exchange of goods and services, and answers questions like: Why do countries trade? What do they trade? What are the consequences of trade? How is it regulated by policy? The second deals with the monetary side of the international economy, i.e. the exchange of assets, and focuses in particular on how the exchange rate between two currencies is determined.

Although macroeconomic quantities are at the core of the analysis, a microeconomic perspective is also often employed. Furthermore, the nature of the subject implies that international economists frequently find inspiration elsewhere for their applications, for example from geography, econometrics, development economics, monetary economics, industrial organisation, etc. This approach results in a rich diversity of insights, nonetheless characterised by a remarkable coherence.

  Leerdoelen After completing this course, the students will:
  • understand the benefits and costs of international trade;
  • be familiar with alternative theoretical models for explaining international trade;
  • understand the relationships between exchange rates, interest rates and price levels.

lecturers: ['D Favoino, MSc', 'dr. J Emami Namini', 'dr. LDS Hering']
text:
Inhoud

The course international economics focuses primarily on the world economy as such and the relationships between countries and trading blocks regarding international trade, capital flows, economic growth, exchange rates and financial crises. Although macroeconomic quantities are at the core of the analysis, these will usually be built up from a microeconomics perspective. The nature of the analysis implies that international economists frequently find inspiration elsewhere for their applications, for example from economic geography, monetary economics, econometrics, development economics or industrial organization. This approach results in a rich diversity of insights, nonetheless characterized by a remarkable coherence.

Leerdoelen
  • To understand the basic theories and concepts in the theory of international trade, as well as in international finance.
  • To gain knowledge about the world economy as such and the relationships between countries and trading blocks regarding international trade, capital flows, economic growth, exchange rates and financial crises.
  • To gain understanding of the macroeconomic relations at the core of the analysis of the world economy, but to understand that these relations are usually built up from a microeconomics perspective.
  • To gain knowledge about how international economics frequently is inspired by topics from, for example, geography, monetary economics, econometrics, development or industrial organization.

lecturers: ['dr. J Emami Namini', 'prof.dr. EM Bosker']
text:
Inhoud
Instructors: Prof. F.J.G.M. Klaassen (UvA), Dr J. Emami Namini (EUR) and Prof. M. Bosker (EUR)
 
Course description:

International interdependencies have long been important for economic policy, and globalization has further strengthened that relevance. This holds not only for small open economies, such as the Netherlands, but also for Europe and worldwide. This course provides basic insights based on micro foundations to better understand such interdependencies, both from a theoretical and empirical viewpoint. The course covers international trade as well as international finance.

The international trade part starts with a discussion of modern quantitative trade models, focusing on their implication for welfare in different countries as well as that of heterogeneous firms within a country. The last session then focusses on how to assess the models’ welfare implications in the data. We discuss influential empirical papers that study not only the aggregate welfare effects of trade, but that also highlight the importance of considering the distributional consequences of trade
within a country.

The international finance part of the course starts from the view of the current account as a vehicle for intertemporal trade, driven by optimizing behavior of agents, which helps to analyze topics such as global imbalances and sustainability of foreign debt. We also discuss interest rate parities, floating nominal exchange rates, speculative attacks on fixed rates, sticky prices and exchange rate
volatility, quantifying pressure on the forex market for any exchange rate regime, and the relevance of exchange market pressure for central bank policy.

Students also have to write a short academic essay in which they apply a theory to a real-life event, for example.

Inhoud
<html>
<head>
	<title></title>
	<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
	<style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
	</style>
</head>
<body>International environmental law (IEL) is an innovative, dynamic, and rapidly developing field that seeks to ameliorate global environmental issues such as the impacts of climate change and marine pollution/exploitation. As the causes, effects, and potential solutions of such global phenomena transcend national boundaries, international cooperation is increasingly important as reflected in a growing number of international environmental agreements governing disparate issues such as nuclear testing, hazardous substances, and atmospheric pollution. This course aims to provide students with an overview of the evolution of international environmental law, as well as an introduction to the major concepts, cases, and principles that shape effective global environmental governance. Throughout the course, attention will be focused on international responses to environmental issues with a transboundary or global scope. Following the introductory lectures, which will set the scene by introducing the major players (international institutions and actors) in the field, students will have an opportunity to explore the role of international law in regulating environmental problems such as marine pollution, climate change, nuclear testing, as well as the governance of outer space, the Arctic, and Antarctica.</body>
</html>

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['prof.dr. JP Cornelissen']
['dr. VV Volosovych']
text:
Inhoud

Since the end of World War II, the international investments and other foreign activities of companies and individuals have grown substantially, and this growth is accelerating in recent decades. Firms of all types and sizes now face decisions about how to best obtain and allocate resources abroad. At the same time, significant differences in economic development between countries have persisted, and these give rise to considerable variation in the prevalence of market imperfections. Consequently, basic financial decisions now involve cross-border complexities.

This course shows how macro-level forces of trade, investment, and finance result from and, conversely, affect the micro-level actions of firms and households. In examining the key issues in international finance, we will focus on recent developments and incorporate theoretical, empirical, policy, and institutional dimensions.

The course begins with introduction describing the key trends and developments of the global economy and financial markets in the recent decades and discussing three main benefits of financial globalization: efficient investment, international risk sharing, and discipline effect on macroeconomic or corporate policies. We will also discuss one major cost of financial globalization, the sovereign debt and default.

The rest of the course is split into the two main parts: International investments and International business.

The topics covered in the International investments part include equity asset pricing in international context, foreign exchange returns, currency markets, and currency risk, international investment anomalies, and issues related international diversification of investment risk (or international risk sharing).

In the second part, we will touch upon selected issues related to the international activities at the micro (firm) level. This includes basic theory and key stylized facts about the multinational companies and selected issues related to practical international investing and international operations by the firms.

We try to arrange a guest lecture covering the practical aspects of the lecture material.

Leerdoelen

Knowledge

  • Understand and interpret macroeconomic concepts in the context of a globalized economy.
  • Understand of the theoretical mechanisms that determine the evolution of the global economic environment and its influence on domestic financial markets.
  • Learn the theory of how financial globalization affect pricing of internationally traded equity assets. Reconcile the empirical evidence with the theoretical predictions of the models.
  • Describe the behavior of foreign exchange returns, based on the theoretical framework introduced in the lecture on global asset pricing.
  • Learn the patterns in the data and theories explaining the international capital flows and the international investment anomalies.
  • Get familiar with the scholarly and policy debate about the benefits and costs of financial globalization.
  • Understand the reasons for emergence and examine the role of multinational firms. Learn about decisions, risks, and practical issues facing companies participating in international markets. Analyze and discuss financial problems corporations face that result from operating in an international environment.

Skills

  • Read and critically evaluate academic and policy papers related to international finance.
  • Interpret the key economic news in the context of theory and empirical research covered in the course.
  • Obtain, analyze, present, and interpret the relevant economic and financial data.
  • Learn to apply the econometric techniques for empirical tests of the key relationships related to international finance.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. M Koning']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
This course provides an overview of the key issues in financial reporting. We use International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) as our anchor and relate the requirements for selected topics to the underlying concepts and principles. This will help you learn to make informed judgements and think critically about financial reporting problems. These are necessary skills for your future career, whether you will be preparing, auditing or using financial statements. But perhaps even more importantly, this course examines the international and political processes that shape the accounting standards and practices in Europe and the rest of the world. For every selected reporting topic, we take a step back to look at the underlying problem and critically evaluate the solution that the current standards provide.

Financial reporting is a powerful tool that influences the allocation of scarce resources across market participants. Although the IFRS Conceptual Framework identifies investors as the primary users of financial reports, we consider the economic consequences and impact on other stakeholders and society at large. The current accounting standards and practices are central to this course, but we critically discuss the limitations of financial statements. In addition to the traditional, shareholder-oriented view of financial reporting, we explore alternative views as guided by the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals (SDG’s). We discuss the challenges of measuring and reporting a firm’s performance and financial position, in a changing business environment. The course contributes to developing a critical mindset that helps you to address the challenges of financial reporting and your knowledge on how your decisions and actions, as a future financial manager, accountant or controller, affect investors, other stakeholders and society. Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
On completion of this course, students will be able to:
  1. Demonstrate an understanding of the international, institutional environment of financial reporting, its limitations and challenges;
  2. Apply and discuss the main provisions and criteria of the accounting standards covered in this course;
  3. Use underlying principles and concepts to critically evaluate financial reporting decisions;
  4. Make informed judgements for financial reporting issues in the problem areas that are covered in this course;
  5. Compile financial statement items from fact patterns compliant with the standards covered in this course;
  6. Critically evaluate the current state of financial reporting and challenges of alternative perspectives on integrated reporting.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. ME Foldes', 'mr. CA Bol', 'mr. M Timmers']
text:
Inhoud This course focuses on the impact of international treaty law on regulating health care systems. Therefore, this course starts with identifying the underlying principles of health law. These principles explain the ratio of regulatory intervention in health care, i.e. good health. Good health raises questions about access to medical care, human rights and health care, scarcity of resources, mobility of patients, health professionals and medical products, and market competition in health care. To a large extent these questions are influenced by legal standards as defined by international treaty law. Leerdoelen
  • The course aims at increasing knowledge of the international legal framework on human rights in health care
  • The student will be able to analyze contemporary legal problems and dilemmas in health care access, and other patients’ rights, and apply this knowledge on similar issues
  • The student will be able to analyze contemporary legal problems and dilemmas in allocating health care services with respect to vulnerable groups
  • The student will be able to analyze court rulings on enforcing health care rights
  • The student will be able to formulate relevant legal arguments in the patients’ rights debate

lecturers: ['mr.dr. AP den Exter']
text:
Inhoud The purpose of this course is to add a human rights dimension to the overall health law program of the ESL-master Recht van de gezondheidszorg. Students will be introduced to the human rights framework with a view to enable them to conceptualize issues from a human rights perspective. A substantial portion of the course will then be spent on exploring the Right to Health through various regional and international mechanisms. After having considered health and human rights protection of so-called vulnerable groups (i.e. children, women, prisoners) in some detail, the focus finally shifts towards human rights case law. Since human rights protection is organized at various levels, attention is paid to United Nations human rights law as well as to human rights law as developed by the Council of Europe.      Leerdoelen
  • The student obtains a thorough understanding of international human rights law relating to health issues.
  • The student acquires knowledge of international human rights law relating to health issues as developed within the contexts of the United Nations and the Council of Europe.
  • The student is able to apply his newly acquired knowledge and understanding of international health law, implying that:
  • he is able to recognize the relevant human rights aspects of a case;
  • he is able to apply relevant human rights law to a case;
  • he can come up with a logical answer to legal questions arising out of a case, by applying relevant human rights law.
  • The student demonstrates a critical attitude during lectures and seminars.
  • The student is able to express himself adequately in English, verbally as well as in writing.

Inhoud The course adopts a holistic approach to learning international human rights law, beginning from its normative foundations and emergence as a distinct field of international law to its contemporary status and challenges for the future. Given the introductory nature of this course, emphasis is placed throughout on idealism as well as realism, including an understanding of how international and domestic politics have influenced and continue to influence the field of international human rights law. On the normative side, participants will analyses the merits and demerits of categorizing human rights under different labels and its effects on human rights promotion. They will look at case studies from around the world that expose the tensions between cultural relativism and universality of human rights, and will also look at the concepts of collective rights and rights of vulnerable persons. On the practical side, participants will be introduced to the most important mechanisms as well as challenges to the realisation and promotion of human rights, including State compliance and judicial enforcement. Finally, the inter-play between nation-states and civil society will be scrutinised with a strong focus on NGO activism and the emerging challenges thereto.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. S Nguyen']
text:
Inhoud Practices of journalism vary considerably, depending on the wider - local, national and even transnational (Al Jazeera, CNN) - contexts in which they take place. Departing from some of the main benchmarks in (Western) journalism with regard to training, routines, formats, organization, ethics and culture, this course familiarizes students with the field of journalism studies from the perspective of foreign correspondence and their journalistic practices across the globe. This entails gaining insight in the obstacles correspondents meet when working in non-democratic, non-free environments. This course combines theory, research and practice related to foreign correspondence. Students learn about the concrete work experiences from correspondents themselves, they learn to reflect on these experiences from an academic perspective and to relate their learned insights to international journalism in general.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • Key concepts and approaches in journalism studies and international journalism research
  • What international journalists are, and what international and global journalism involves
  • How and why journalistic practices and international news coverage vary across different contexts
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Analyze, compare and critically reflect upon journalistic practices using concepts and theories covered in this course

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['mr.dr. JA van Ast', 'prof.dr. M Onderco']
text:
Inhoud This course is about international law and how it can be used to tackle international social challenges, such as conflicts or climate change.

International law can be conceived as a specific kind of rules. In the national legal setting, there are authorities making law and judges bound to the application and interpretation of existing law when judging. However, in the international law, almost all legal power needs to be voluntarily accepted by states. That creates unique challenges for using law to address the most pressing rules. However, similarly to domestic law, international law is about formulating and interpreting social norms. As such it contributes to creating and upholding social order. Hence, the law and the state are inextricably linked.

At the domestic level, the law pertains to the rights and duties that individuals have vis a vis each other as well as those between states and individuals. The rules regulating contacts within the society of states are generally called international law. One of the aims of international law is to address cross border societal problems in a peaceful way. Traditionally international law is based on national sovereignty which means that there is no authority above states. However, over time states have empowered non-state actors with supranational (or intergovernmental) authorities such as the international organizations that are part of the UN family. This development has fundamentally changed international law as it means that states have surrendered some of their sovereignty to these international organizations. Consequently, modern international law includes also other actors than states, such as international organizations, private actors and even citizens.

The first part of this course deals with the basics of law in modern society. It addresses questions such as: what is law, where can it be found, how is it organized into different domains, and how is it related to the state? It also shows the development and evolution of international law, including its sources, subjects, and institutions.

The second part of the course focuses on the application of international law to the main international challenges today – war, environment, and technology. In this part, we will focus on how international law enables – but also hampers – the development of effective frameworks to deal with international social challenges. Today, addressing such challenges requires bringing in a broader set of actors, and new forms of institutions.

The conceptual focus of law and regulation is illustrated with the handling of cross-national social problems, spurred on by a globalizing economy. The first part of the course aims at answering corresponding questions with a comprehensive introduction in the study of international law. The second part of the course reflects on the changing role of international law in addressing today’s main challenges in international law. Leerdoelen After following this course, the student is able to:

1. reproduce the basic concepts of law in modern society;
2. place conflicts, questions and issues in the different fields of law;
3. describe the most important changes in the relationship between law and states during recent history;
4. explain the basics of international law including its most important sources, subjects, and institutions;
5. explain how international law affects different social challenges.

lecturers: ['dr. A Naudé - Fourie', 'dr. I Kampourakis', 'dr. M Stambulski']
text:
Inhoud International Law and Global Governance juxtaposes the traditional system of public international law with the evolving system of global governance, examining how international law shifts from an inter-state system to a multi-actor system of law.
  Leerdoelen Students are able to identify important actors in international law-making, including non-traditional actors, illustrate how new processes of global governance affect public international law and evaluate the growing privatization of public international law.

course_title: International Law in Practice: Moot Court
text:
Inhoud

Moot court is a simulation of a fictional dispute between countries before the International Courts. Students prepare oral and written pleadings arguing both the applicant and respondent positions of the case. The students analyze the problem, identify the legal issues, research the law, write the briefs and orally present in front of an international tribunal, like the real-life lawyers do.

A team of EUC students will participate in Telders International Law Moot Court Competition, which is organized by Leiden University. Each year student teams are presented with a case involving a fictitious dispute between two States, which is brought before the International Court of Justice (ICJ). It is up to the teams to defend the two States to the best of their abilities.

In Telders International Law Moot Court Competition the students' written and oral argumentations are judged by legal experts such as judges from the ICJ(Telders' Final in the Peace Palace), other international courts, delegates from the International Committee of the Red Cross and professors of law guaranteeing high intellectual standards and the prestige of these Competitions. Therefore, participation in these Moot Courts is a strong asset especially for the students who wish to do a Masters Degree in International Law.

Throughout four quads, weekly meetings will be held (contact hours 2-3 hours per week), readings will be assigned, and student preparation is expected at individual and group level. The students will be closely supervised by the coaches. The deadlines for the assessments will be known provided once the competition cases and timelines will bear published. Please keep in mind that these deadlines might fall within the Winter Break, which could mean that some work would be required during the breaks.

Leerdoelen

At the end of this course students will:

  • learn to present a well-structured legal argument, both in writing and orally.
  • develop skills to use norms of Public International Law
  • conduct legal research individually and in a team
  • solve cases in the public international law field by identifying the applicable law

Achievement levels

The following achievement levels apply with regard to the course:

  • The student is able to write a memo concerning a specific legal question.
  • The student is able to make a persuasive oral presentation before a panel of three judges/practitioners/experts.

text:

Students prepare oral and written pleadings arguing both the applicant and respondent positions of the case.
