Please visit STiP for more information.

course_title: Introductie Financieel Management van de Gezondheidszorg
college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. S Sülz', 'dr.ir. SG Elkhuizen', 'drs. A Braam', 'drs. R Belle', 'M Leusder, MSc', 'MA van den Berg']
text:
Inhoud Inhoud
Financieel management is onderdeel van het dagelijks reilen en zeilen van elke organisatie, niet in de laatste plaats binnen de gezondheidszorg. Het vak Introductie Financieel Management van de Gezondheidszorg biedt een palet aan handvatten hiertoe. Financieel management omvat een groot aantal kennisgebieden, waaronder het berekenen van kosten en opbrengsten van de bedrijfsvoering, maar ook het toepassen van deze informatie als stuur- en beslisinformatie ten behoeve van het management van de zorgorganisatie. De doelstelling van het vak is de student kennis te laten nemen van de belangrijkste aspecten van financieel management.
 
Gelet op de breedte van het vakgebied heeft het vak een inleidend karakter. Er is een keuze gemaakt uit een aantal voor de zorg relevante basisonderwerpen. In dit vak wordt een introductie gegeven in de bedrijfseconomische/financiële aspecten ten behoeve van het management van gezondheidszorgorganisaties. Centraal in dit vak staan de volgende onderdelen:
  • De productie van bedrijfseconomische/financiële informatie
Tijdens de eerste 3 weken komt dit deelaspect aan bod. We behandelen de kosten van duurzame productiemiddelen en van producten/diensten in de zorg. Ook analyseren we afwijkingen van onze ramingen aan de hand van de verschillenanalyse.
  • De toepassing van de bedrijfseconomische/financiële informatie
De tweede helft van het vak (weken 4 t/m 6) richt zich op de toepassing van de bedrijfseconomische/financiële informatie. We zien hoe deze informatie wordt ingezet om gedrag in de organisatie te sturen. Ook behandelen we investeringsbeslissingen en het jaarverslag.
Ondanks het inleidende karakter van het vak, is het voor studenten die geen (recente) ervaring hebben met het vakgebied, aan te raden om – voorafgaand aan dit vak – door middel van zelfstudie het ingangsniveau te halen. Als indicatie voor het ingangsniveau hanteren wij het boek Introductie basisbegrippen bedrijfseconomie & bedrijfsadministratie (Heezen, 2015). Dit boek wordt aanbevolen als zelfstudiemateriaal (met name hoofdstukken 1, 2, en 3 t/m 3.3) voor studenten met onvoldoende voorkennis.

Inrichting van het onderwijs
Het vak is opgebouwd uit literatuur, (online video) colleges, Q&A sessies, oefencasuïstiek & zelfstudie-opdrachten, werkgroepen, inleveropdrachten en tentamens. CANVAS wordt intensief als communicatiemiddel gebruikt. Aangezien dit vakgebied een voorbeeld is van toegepaste wetenschap, is dit vak te typeren als een echt doe-vak. Dit betekent dat je inzicht opbouwt door met casuïstiek aan de slag te gaan. Door voldoende te oefenen ontwikkelt zich het inzicht en de vaardigheid in het vakgebied. Centraal staat je eigen zelfwerkzaamheid, waarbij je oefent met diverse opgaven. Dit wordt ondersteund met werkgroepen. In deze werkgroepen worden onder andere de door jou voorbereide opgaven behandeld en wordt hierop gereflecteerd.
 
Het theoretisch kader van de onderscheiden thema’s worden ingeleid en uitgediept in de colleges. Ter ondersteuning wordt casuïstiek als concrete voorbeelden in de colleges gebruikt. Voor zover mogelijk word je geactiveerd door deze voorbeelden aan te vullen of aanvullende vragen in te vullen. Ook de plaats van de bedrijfseconomische analyses in de besluitvorming binnen de zorg komt regelmatig aan de orde en wordt gereflecteerd. De collegesheets staan op CANVAS, die je zelf kunt downloaden.
 
 
Leerdoelen Leerdoelen
  • Je kunt de begrippen kosten en opbrengsten onderscheiden van uitgaven en ontvangsten en de verschillende kostensoorten benoemen en uitrekenen.
  • Je kunt kosten- en kostprijsmodellen evenals verkoopprijsmodellen kwantitatief toepassen en de keuze beargumenteren voor een bepaald kostenmodel.
  • Je kunt een onderbouwde afweging maken van een investeringsbeslissing door alternatieve investeringsselectie-methoden kwantitatief toe te passen.
  • Je bent in staat ter wille van monitoring, planning en financiële sturing om een verschillenanalyse kwantitatief uit te voeren en de resultaten te interpreteren.
  • Je bent in staat om een jaarrekening te lezen en een financiële ratio analyse kwantitatief uit tevoren en met financieel management te interpreteren.

course_title: Introductie Financieel Management van de Gezondheidszorg
college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. S Sülz', 'drs. A Braam', 'drs. R Belle', 'M Leusder, MSc', 'MA van den Berg']

lecturers: ['dr. LC van Hulten', 'dr. YM Tigelaar - Klootwijk', 'drs. C van Wijk', 'drs. MHM Smeets', 'J Gruson', 'mr. MPL Adriaansen', 'mr. TC Hoogwout', 'prof.dr. P Kavelaars', 'Y Vink']
text:
Inhoud

Gedurende een achttal colleges van twee uren wordt de student vertrouwd gemaakt met de fiscale studierichting. Met name de volgende onderdelen komen aan de orde:

  • Kennismaking met diverse fiscale vakken in de vorm van korte colleges
  • Kennismaking met actuele fiscale ontwikkelingen die zich in de maatschappij voordoen
  • Kennismaken met de wijze waarop in de praktijk met fiscale economie wordt omgegaan.
Leerdoelen
  • Begrijpen van actuele fiscale ontwikkelingen die zich in het maatschappelijk verkeer voordoen en begrijpen hoe in de dagelijkse praktijk met fiscale economie wordt omgegaan.
Extra Studenten die in een eerder studiejaar het bachelor-1 Economie en Bedrijfseconomie hebben afgerond en verder studeren in het bachelor-2 Fiscale Economie, zijn vrijgesteld van dit vak.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. TL Koren', 'EDAM Hermans, MA']
text:
Inhoud Kunst- en cultuurbeleid staat voor de bemoeienis van de overheid (rijk, provincies en gemeenten) met de cultuursector. Kunst- en cultuurbeleid is een betrekkelijk modern fenomeen. In Nederland is er eigenlijk pas na de Tweede Wereldoorlog sprake van een kunstbeleid. Sinds die tijd is de Nederlandse overheid sterk verbonden met de kunstwereld via het subsidiëren van de productie en consumptie van cultuur, maar ook via het stelsel van sociale zekerheid.

In deze cursus gaan we op zoek naar een antwoord op de vraag waarom de Nederlandse overheid ertoe besluit om te interveniëren in de kunstwereld. Welke redenen voert zij daarvoor aan? Om een gedegen antwoord op deze vraag te formuleren, duiken studenten - na een introductie op wat overheidsbeleid in het algemeen en kunstbeleid in het bijzonder precies is - in de geschiedenis van het Nederlandse kunstbeleid. Uit die specifieke geschiedenis of sociale wording van het Nederlandse kunstbeleid kan al veel worden geconcludeerd over de vraag naar de legitimatie van kunst- en cultuurbeleid. Tevens wordt ingegaan op de belangrijkste economische motieven om een kunstbeleid te voeren, en staan studenten stil bij wetenschappelijk onderzoek naar de effecten van kunstbeleid, dat nagaat of de overheid er in slaagt haar voorgestelde beleid te realiseren.
Het vak Kunst- en Cultuurbeleid is een inleiding op de belangrijkste wetenschappelijke motieven en onderzoekingen van cultuurbeleid, met name het cultuurbeleid in Nederland. Het vormt als zodanig een inleiding op latere vakken in de BA- en MA fase.


  Leerdoelen
Dit vak maakt studenten vertrouwd met de geschiedenis van het Nederlandse kunst- en cultuurbeleid, en daarnaast met de belangrijkste economische en sociologische theorieën achter overheidsbemoeienis met de kunstwereld. Na afloop van de cursus is de student in staat om:
 
1.de belangrijkste ontwikkelingen binnen de geschiedenis van het Nederlandse kunst- en cultuurbeleid te kennen en doorgronden;
2.deze historische ontwikkelingen in een sociologisch perspectief te plaatsen;
3.de belangrijkste economische motieven voor overheidsbemoeienis met de kunst en cultuursector te kennen;
4.een kritische en wetenschappelijke blik te werpen op mogelijke effecten van kunst- en cultuurbeleid.
 
In de werkcolleges krijgen de academische vaardigheden ‘presenteren’ en ‘academisch schrijven’ speciale aandacht. Er wordt o.a. uitgebreid aandacht besteed aan het schrijven van een beleidsadvies, waar studenten gedurende de cursus in teams aan werken.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. CHO Schmitt', 'dr. MMJE Cosemans', 'dr. RJ Dottling, MSc', 'dr. T Lambert', 'prof.dr. D Metzger', 'prof.dr. D Schoenmaker', 'prof.dr. DGJ Bongaerts', 'prof.dr. PGJ Roosenboom']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The course overviews the main areas of finance, namely corporate finance and governance, entrepreneurial finance, asset management, and banking. It exposes the classical questions in each of these areas and then presents newly emerging topics, such as changes triggered by FinTech innovations or sustainability issues. All topics are approached from an academic and practical angle. Finance faculty links the topics to both core and elective courses. Guest speakers discuss the topics from a practical perspective.

The overall aim is to give students a broad introduction to the MScF&I program by covering key academic concepts in finance in connection to their practical relevance, but also, and most importantly, to get to know each other (fellow students, staff and faculty) before getting started with the course work! Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
At the end of this course:
  • Students will get acquainted with the main finance areas, namely corporate finance, entrepreneurial finance, asset management, and banking
  • Students will be able to understand the dynamics of current topics for financial practice
  • Students will be able to explain the link between academic concepts and finance practice
  • Students will be introduced to each other and to faculty (and vice versa)

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['M.T. van Berckel Bik']

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. D. Jaarsma', 'E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen']

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. ir. J.J.M. Pel', 'E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. RL Hewett', 'RF Dias Covas', 'S van Loosen', 'WJ Tahir Shah']
text:
Inhoud This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:
  • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
  • What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
  • What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
  • How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?
Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed. Leerdoelen In this short introduction course, you will learn which steps to take before you start writing. We will focus on the following questions: which journal is best for publishing my paper? How do you plan the writing process and find the adequate literature? Furthermore, we will be looking at the structure of an academic paper, typical academic language and reader friendliness.
 
The format of this course is a 3-hour workshop in which theory and practical exercises will be alternated. To wrap up, you will do a post-course assignment and get individual feedback on your writing.

lecturers: ['dr. FM Elfers', 'dr. PYE Leung']
text:
Inhoud
  • Introduction to empirical research in Accounting and Finance
  • Applied theory and hypothesis development
  • The predictive validity framework
  • Experiments versus observational studies
  • Basic applied econometrics: Causality and identification
Leerdoelen
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: Formulation of research questions, application of theory, and development of testable hypotheses in empirical accounting research.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: Applied econometrics and causal inference in accounting research; (dis)advantages of experiments vs. observational studies.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Unless there are any pandemic-related restrictions, we will return to on-campus lectures in the academic year 2022/2023.

lecturers: ['B Van Os, MSc', 'dr. E Oldenkamp - Bazsa']
text:
Inhoud
  • Mathematical Logic
  • Set Theory
  • Mathematical and Strong Induction
  • Sequences and Series
  • Elementary functions and their graphs
  • Combination, inverse and limits of functions
  • Analytic Trigonometry and the unit circle
  • The concept of the derivative of a function with a single variable
  • Partial derivatives of a function of multiple variables
  • The Lagrange multiplier method
  • Integrals

This course is required for FEB21018X Introduction to Statistics, FEB21019X Matrix Algebra, FEB21020X Microeconomics and FEB21021X Analysis.

Leerdoelen
  • Being able to correctly use concepts and notations from set theory.
  • To raise the abstraction level.
  • Performing a correct mathematical proof with the right notation and right logic.
  • To learn mathematical proving techniques, such as set proofs, mathematical and complete induction.
  • Learning the computation of limits of sequences and functions.
  • Getting to master the basics about functions, such as drawing a graph and the basic properties of functions.
  • Becoming familiar with real valued functions of multiple variables and their properties necessary for the use of the Lagrange multiplier method, including partial and directional derivatives.
  • To become familiar with the Lagrange multiplier method.
  • To master part of the techniques of integration.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar 1 midterm counting for 15% of the final grade.
No grade for the assignments.

lecturers: ['dr. JTR Stoop', 'dr. M de Vries Mecheva', 'F Capozza', 'prof.dr. KIM Rohde']
text:
Inhoud

Economics typically assumes that people behave like "Homo Economicus". Homo Economicus is a rational and selfish person without cognitive limits. Psychology has shown that people do not behave like Homo Economicus. Consequently, economic and financial models can lead to the wrong predictions and policy recommendations. This course will give an overview of the limitations of traditional economic and financial models and how they can be improved upon by using psychological insights. The course will enable students to have a deeper and more critical look at their own profession and to learn how better economic and financial policy can be made.

Leerdoelen
  • Students learn the basic assumptions about decision making that are traditionally made in economics.
  • Students learn examples where these basic assumptions are violated.
  • Students see a few examples of what these violations of traditional economics mean in terms of economic policy.
  • Students learn the basic terminology used in economic experiments
  • Students learn to recognise whether observed behaviour violates standard economic decision making models or not.
  • Students learn to predict behaviour based on standard economic decision making models.
  • Students get acquainted with economic experiments and the decisions to be made when designing such experiments.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The tutorials are on campus. The lectures are on campus if possible. Extra Students can do an online test (= interim test) each week. They can earn bonus questions for the exam and resit within the same academic year.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. S. Uitte de Willige', 'dr. S.E. Hoeks', 'dr. S.J. Baart', 'prof. dr. B.E. Hansen', 'prof. dr. I. Kardys']
text:
Inhoud

Course description 
This course provides an introduction to statistics for medical research. Without focusing too much on the underlying mathematics, students will learn the most important concepts, statistical tests and software to be able to perform statistical analyses. Additionally, they will obtain skills to help them conduct responsible science and critically read study protocols and published papers.  

This course is module I from the modules on statistics. It is a precursory course before the R course (module II), survival analysis course (module III) and the course on prediction models (module IV). 

Learning goals  
After completing of the course, the student should:  

  • Understand the difference between descriptive and inferential statistics;  
  • Understand the basics of hypothesis testing and p-values;  
  • Be familiar with the most important statistical tests for comparing groups and regression analysis such as chi-square, t-test, linear and logistic regression;  
  • Understand the underlying assumptions and limitations of these techniques;  
  • Be able to perform basic statistical analysis in SPSS or R and interpret the results.

Assessments 
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course 
This course includes mandatory attendance. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points.
Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, students may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Students should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.
The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.     
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’. 

Evaluation 
Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.  

No certificates 
Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved. 

Cancellation policy  
Erasmus MC Graduate School charges a cancellation fee of €75 for all cancellations made more than 22 days before the start of the course. Fifty percent of the course fee, with a minimum of €75, is due for cancellations made between 21 and 10 days before the start date. The full course fee is due for cancellations made less than 10 days before the start date, or in case of no-show without cancellation. For Erasmus MC PhD candidates the full course fee in case of the cancellation policy will be the equivalent of the number of course days times €100. All invoices will be sent to the head of department or for external participants to the e-mail address provided upon registration. Those who register for a PhD course agree with these financial conditions.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. JJ Nijholt', 'dr. RL Olie', 'dr. S Liu', 'J Duijsters, MSc', 'M van Ast', 'prof.dr. JP Cornelissen', 'prof.dr. SP Kaptein', 'prof.dr. TH Reus']
text:
Inhoud

Course overview

This course introduces students to the field of business administration, the firm and its context.  As such, this course serves as introduction and background to your bachelor programme.  We do this by discussing three interrelated levels (1) the environmental level, (2) the organizational level (3), and the strategic level of the business context.

The context of firms has changed profoundly over the last years and decades. Technological developments, global integration, the global pandemic, climate change have changed the way we think about businesses and their behavior, and therefore calls for firms to reconsider their ways of organizing and strategizing.  This course offers an introduction to core topics, established theories and key concepts to help students not only understand the roots of business thinking but also be better able to navigate the current and future business landscape.

We begin by introducing the general framework of the course and present a brief history of business thinking. We then first zoom out to consider the environmental context of firms, focusing on current global trends and changes. We pay particular attention to the international context in terms of both the institutional and cultural frameworks in which firms do business.  Next, we consider the organizational context of firms, focusing on core features particularly in terms of how to organize businesses and people across borders. Finally, we consider the strategic context of firms, focusing on the competitive environment as well as the context in which management form and implement strategies. This strategizing occurs not only in the competitive environment but also in the broader societal context, which makes it important to consider also the ethics and corporate social responsibility of firms. Leerdoelen

Learning goals:

At the end of this course students should be able to:
  • Discuss the main tenets and underlying assumptions of historical periods of management thought.
  • Describe and discuss systems theory of organizations in their environment.
  • Explain the drivers of globalization and its consequences for business and economies.
  • Identify distinct economic, political and legal systems and how they affect the business context.
  • Explain and compare the role of institutional frameworks in shaping a country`s business environment, and their effects on the way firms operate, including internationally.
  • Recognize, understand, and explain the challenges associated with organizing, and organizing internationally in particular, in order to meet often conflicting demands.
  • Understand the key people and roles of the upper echelons in the firm. 
  • Discuss basic concepts and different schools of thought in strategic management, including competitive, corporate and global strategy.
  • Describe and compare various conceptions of business ethics and corporate social responsibility and illustrate ways in which the UN Sustainable Development Goals affect firm behavior.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. FH Wijen', 'dr. Z Wu', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text: Inhoud We will discuss Research Data Management (RDM) as a strategy for your data and research. You will get familiar with RDM processes and the Data Management Plan Template. We will show you examples of how-to fill-in the template and we will have a hands-on session on which you will have time to fill-in and get answers to all your questions about your own Data Management Plan.

course_title: Introduction to Commodity Trade and Supply Networks
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['RC Sluijk', 'WAA Jacobs']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Commodities are critical for the global economy as they literally power the world, feed the planet and provide the essential inputs in all the devices (e.g. smartphones) and household appliances (e.g. shampoo) that make our lives easy. Commodity trading involves the transformation of commodities in time (through storage), space (through shipping) and form (through processing). Commodity trading firms (CTFs) such as Vitol, Trafigura and Cargill are for a large part responsible for the supply and delivery of commodities to their clients, often large manufacturing firms, in which they take on (and offset) various forms of risks (e.g. price volatility, geopolitics, the weather, foreign currency exchange and operational risks such as delays in delivery) for their clients. Commodity trading thus involves highly dynamic information-intensive tasks and capabilities in the field of logistics, finance and technology.

The value of the world’s traded commodities is estimated to be around 6 trillion US$ annually. The way supply chains of physical commodities are managed by various trading firms and how these trading firms are capable of securing delivery to clients under volatile and risky conditions is the topic of the course. No better place to study this than in Rotterdam:  Europe’s gateway for the global trade in physical commodities. Rotterdam forms the heart of the ARA-region (Amsterdam-Rotterdam-Antwerp), a global price reference point for crude oil and used as geographical benchmark in many commodity delivery contracts and freight prices. Commodity traders make use of the port to ship the commodities to markets and many have actual logistical assets (tank storage and warehouses) and processing operations (e.g. refineries)  in the port in addition to the trade desks,  supply chain support functions, head offices or holdings in the city.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The aim of this course is to provide a clear understanding of the important role that commodity traders play in global supply chains and to gain both hard analytical skills and soft skills required to work in dynamic, multinational commodity trading operations.

After the course, students should be able to:
  1. Understand worldwide supply and demand patterns of the most important commodity product groups (energy, metals/minerals, agricultural)
  2. Comprehend the way commodity markets (physical and derivative) function and the role that commodity trading firms play in the worldwide physical delivery of commodities, including contracting, financing and shipping.
  3. Comprehend the various forms of risks involved in commodity trading and how these can be mitigated.
  4. Analyze specific commodity markets and synthesize these analyses into (short term) trading strategies and (long term) strategic decision-making
  5. Present analytical results to a professional audience.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. TA Calkins III', 'dr. V Morea', 'EW Vermunt', 'I Vitola', 'PM Mogos, MSc']
text:
Inhoud Cultural policy could be defined as the intervention of governments for culture. One important form of government intervention is directly subsidizing art organisations and individual artists. However, government support does also take place through tax incentives, support to entrepreneurship, and the social security system.
In this introductory course, students will be acquainted with the major economic and sociological theories of cultural policy. In addition, students will be provided with substantial knowledge of the actual organisation of cultural policy in several European and non-European countries. During the weekly tutorials students work on preparing and presenting a case study on recent developments in cultural policy. Besides, students will discuss recent developments in cultural policy, on the basis of a paper that students write throughout the course. Leerdoelen
This course will introduce students to economic, sociological and historical theory as well as empirical research on government intervention for culture.

lecturers: ['dr. A Tetereva']
text:
Inhoud

Data science provides a new paradigm for the analysis of data. In this course, an introductory overview is given of data science. The main goal is to introduce several data science techniques. Amongst the techniques discussed are (penalized) linear and logistic regression including ridge, lasso, and elastic net regression, and principal components analysis. The techniques are categorized in supervised and unsupervised learning methods. Special attention is given to the bias-variance trade-off and penalty approaches that reduce the variance in prediction at the cost of some bias. The practical implication is to use cross validation to select optimal parameters with respect to predictive performance. The differences between statistical and computational approaches such as bootstrap and permutation testing for hypothesis testing are also discussed. Students apply the methods using the statistical language R in several group assignments.

Leerdoelen
  • Learn the difference between supervised and unsupervised learning
  • Understanding of basic data science methods and concepts
  • Having a broad overview of the area of data science
  • Understanding the bias-variance trade-off
  • Being able to apply discussed data science techniques and report this in a short article
  • Reporting of academic research in the form of a presentation
  • Reflect on academic research
  • Work in a team

course_title: Introduction to Data Science with Python
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. PB Cornelius']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Business analytics and data science are becoming key drivers of competitive advantage. Only firms that can harness their data and develop strong analytic capabilities across all their business functions will be able to survive in fast-moving modern markets. In this course, students will take a first step in this direction, as they learn how to use Python to manage and analyse large data sets. 

Coding is a key component of this course. Students need to be comfortable writing code by themselves. To be able to follow this course, students need to have sufficient prior coding experience (at least at the level of BIM Research Methods I).

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
After this course, students are able to: 
  • write basic applications in Python; 
  • acquire, process, and analyse data using Python; 
  • interpret, present, and communicate the results of statistical analyses.

lecturers: ['dr. MH Akyuz', 'dr. PC Bouman']
text:
Inhoud
  • Basic knowledge of computer usage and security
  • Basic understanding of how to solve simple algorithmic problems
  • Information systems in businesses
  • Spreadsheets and spreadsheet models
  • Basics of modeling in spreadsheets
  • Optimization with spreadsheets
  • Introduction to databases
Leerdoelen
  • Identify the importance of ICT in business.
  • Distinguish between spreadsheets and databases.
  • Model a practical economic or business problem in a spreadsheet.
  • Develop a spreadsheet model for optimisation and simulation.
  • Implement and query a small database.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The contents of the course will be the same as last year. It is possible we will curate the video's we use in the Excel part of the course, but in general we aim to keep the learning goals for each part of the course equal. Extra There are no extra costs for students. In order to make the assignments, students can either use a personal computer they already own, or make use of the computers on campus that are available in PC-rooms. If the student has no access to a Microsoft Excel license on their private computer, they can make use the Office 365 license provided by the university to install Microsoft Excel on their private computer. Microsoft Excel is available by default on the campus computers.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. T Kucukyilmaz', 'dr.ir. OR Koppius']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Deep Learning represents one of the most exciting advances in machine learning with many groundbreaking applications being developed in recent years from areas such as image recognition and speech analysis to machine translation and game-play. Underlying these advances are various types deep neural networks and although these can be very technical, in this course we will try to de-mystify them a little bit, so you will be better able to assess the possibilities and limitation in business practice. We will cover three main topics:
  1. Neural Networks 
  2. Recurrent Neural Networks (used particularly in text analysis and time series analysis)
  3. Convolutional Neural Network (used particularly in image processing)

The main focus of this course is practical and emphasizes learning-by-doing: you will be doing a lot of coding in R and in the main project go through the whole CRISP-DM cycle from the real, practical problem to the final model results and proposed deployment. We put you in the role of the ‘analytics translator’: sufficiently grounded in both the technical aspects and the organizational aspects to be able to function as a bridge between the pure specialists in these areas, so that you will understand the technical, organizational and ethical aspects of deep learning applications. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
Overall course goal: at the end of this course, students should be able to apply a basic deep learning model to a practical decision problem and be able to explain the model and its results to relevant stakeholders, both technical and non-technical.

Course subgoals:
  • Understand the basic logic underlying neural networks (NN), convolutional neural networks (CNN) and recurrent neural networks (RNN)
  • Create such a model in a concrete example and evaluate it in technical aspects as well as practical aspects/constraints such as data quality limitations, performance limitations and ethical considerations
  • Develop yourself into a responsible data scientist that is able to:
    • Translate business decisions into deep learning techniques and vice versa
    • Explain and justify those decisions to technical and non-technical stakeholders alike
    • Design, implement and document your model so that it can be easily understood and reused by other data scientists

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. FH Wijen', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'prof.dr. MJCM Verbeek', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text:
Inhoud This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:
  • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
  • What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
  • What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
  • How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?
Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed. Leerdoelen The workhorse of econometrics is the linear regression model combined with Ordinary Least Squares (OLS). It allows researchers to investigate the relationship between two or more variables, controlling for other factors. For example, what is the effect of dividend announcements on stock market prices and investor behavior? Or which factors affect a firm's entry and exit into a market?
This course introduces linear regression, with particular emphasis on its use and interpretation. Attention is given to hypothesis testing, specification search, goodness-of-fit, model interpretation and comparison, and making predictions. Problems of multicollinearity, heteroskedasticity and autocorrelation are also addressed. Several illustrations will be discussed.
 
At the end of this course, participants should be able to estimate regression models using software like Eviews, SPSS or Stata, and to critically evaluate the results.

lecturers: ['dr. M de Vries Mecheva', "dr. TM Marreiros Bago d'Uva", 'prof.dr. PHBF Franses', 'prof.dr. TGM Van Ourti']
text:
Inhoud

In Introduction to Econometrics students will get acquainted with the toolbox for scientific economic research. The focus is on acquiring knowledge and skills useful for fundamental and applied research in both the public and the private sector. The complete cycle of scientific research will be discussed. Research design, conceptual thinking and cross-sectional and time series techniques will be discussed.

Leerdoelen

After taking this course, students:

  • Can apply and interpret Ordinary Least Squares estimation and understand its assumptions.
  • Have tools to address violated assumptions of Ordinary Least Squares. The following topics will be covered: no simple random sampling, functional form, conditional independence (errors-in-variables, omitted variables bias, simultaneous equations bias, sample selection bias) and consistent standard errors.
  • Can use common techniques and concepts for time series data such as dynamic models, stationarity, AR, unit roots and ARCH.
  • Can apply all these methods using Stata software.

lecturers: ['prof.dr. IP van Staveren']

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['AC Crotta']
text:
Inhoud We will deal with central economic concepts such as: the market, supply & demand, elasticity, competition, monopoly. The students learn to deal with these concepts in weekly assignments, and practice applying them in their thinking on the cultural sector. We will deal with questions such as: how do markets work? How does demand respond to changes in price or quality of the product? How do firms achieve their goals subject to the market structure in which they operate? What are the limitations of economic theories? The course will consist of weekly, three-hour, interactive lectures.

  Leerdoelen In this course, students can familiarise themselves with basic economic concepts and how they relate to the cultural sector. After the course, successful students have sufficient knowledge and understanding of economic theory to perform well during the Master of Cultural Economics and Entrepreneurship specialization.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['AC Crotta', 'B Daga, MA', 'dr. C Dalla Chiesa', 'LJLM De Strooper, MA', 'O Vincent']
text:
Inhoud This intensive course provides an introduction to economic theory and how it applies to the cultural sector, the arts and the creative industries. During eight weeks we will deal with essential economic concepts such as the market, supply & demand, elasticity, competition, monopoly, economic growth & development, entrepreneurship and copyright. The students learn to apply these concepts in weekly class-room assignments, and are introduced to their application to cultural sector and creative industries. We will deal with questions such as how do markets work? What is a rational choice? How does demand respond to changes in price or quality of the product? How does competition function in cultural markets? What causes economic  development and what is the role of culture in this process? What is the role of the cultural sector within the wider economy? Does the government have a role in (cultural) markets? What are the limitations of economic theories? What does thinking economically mean?
The goal of this course is to familiarize students with economic theory especially micro-economic theory and how this applies to the cultural sector and the creative economy. After the course, the students should have a basic knowledge and understanding of economic theory, be able to make verbal and written economic arguments, and they should be able to apply these insights to analyze changes in the (cultural) economy.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. CT Witte', 'dr. FH Wijen', 'GC Klop - van Rijswijk', 'prof.dr.ir. J Dul', 'WJ Tahir Shah', 'YL Mok']
text:
Inhoud

The contents of this course comprise all phases of an empirical study, from the specification of its aim against the background of an evaluation of previous research, through decisions about the research strategy (experiment, survey, case study), case/sample selection and measurement decisions, to the production of the study’s results, their interpretation, and their reporting.
The course is structured around current and emerging themes and debates in the methodological literature. Our focus, however, is on the phases preceding the actual data analysis and on a practically relevant emerging data analysis method called Necessary Condition Analysis (NCA).

Leerdoelen The goal of this course is to strengthen and deepen the understanding of the core methodological issues and choices in empirical research.

course_title: Introduction to Forensic and Legal Psychology
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. I Boskovic', 'dr. JDM van Dongen', 'prof.dr. EGC Rassin']
text:
Inhoud In this course, students will be made familiar with the context in which forensic and legal psychologists operate. Potential sources of bias in these areas will be discussed. The concept of criminal responsibility will be tackled.  Also, the likelihood ratio will be introduced. Students are made familiar with symptom validity testing, confession evidence, and dissociative disorders. At the end of this course, students will have a clear view of what forensic and legal psychology is. Leerdoelen Gain insight in the specific role of the forensic and legal psychologist.
Gain insight in bias and other pitfalls for the forensic and legal psychologist.
Become familiar with the concept of criminal (ir)responsibility.
Gain insight in the likelihood ratio approach to evidence evaluation.
Become familiar with specific topics such as SVT, confession evidence, and dissociative disorders.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. S Vanhaverbeke']
text:
Inhoud
According to recent estimates, organizations lose about six percent of their revenues to dishonesty from within the firm. Such occupational frauds occur at various organizational levels – from the mailroom to the boardroom. While executives are “cooking” the company’s books to show better profits (e.g., Enron), purchasing agents are getting kickbacks from suppliers and employees embezzle money to improve their lifestyles. In this minor, we learn who commits fraud and why, what organizations can do to prevent and detect fraud, how affected organizations deal with crises caused by fraud, and how the legal system responds to fraud.
 
Leerdoelen
After following this minor, students will be able to:
  • Understand the costs and personal consequences of fraud occurrences and how it affects individuals, consumers, organizations and society at large;
  • Reproduce famous fraud schemes in history;
  • Understand how pressures, opportunities, and attitudes (the “fraud triangle”) contribute to fraud and identify those;
  • Define fraud and distinguish between different types of fraud;
  • Recognize who commits fraud and why;
  • Identify controls that prevent and detect fraudulent behavior, from the “tone at the top” to security measures on the shop floor;
  • Analyze, present and discuss academic articles, which deal with fraud,
  • Conduct a basic forensic investigation;
  • Obtain a basic understanding of how the legal system deals with occurrences and risks of fraud.

lecturers: ['CC Spall', 'dr. LA Borges Lima', 'FKS Robinson', 'JAJ de Vogel', 'PM Edwards', 'prof.dr. J Jansz', 'V Balan, MSc']
text:
Inhoud The course offers a general introduction to communication as a field of study and research. Communication is defined and described in detail by covering the basic processes involved (e.g. listening and attention, perceiving, using verbal and nonverbal communication). Next, the process of communication is presented in a variety of communication contexts (e.g., interpersonal, small group, public, organizational, intercultural). The course dedicates special attention to the context of media. The textbook provides a broad and accessible introduction to the field. The course material also includes academic articles in order to familiarize students with the products of scientific research. Course activities include, for example, discussion of key issues and questions, in-class exercises, presentations by students and discussions of student assignments. The classroom will be ‘flipped’ partially, by asking students to complete Socrative tests at home and during the lectures. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • The nature and history of communication as a field of social scientific study.
  • The basic theories and principles of communication and how these apply to different (professional) communication contexts across cultures.
Students have the ability and/or propensity to:
  • Apply basic communication concepts and theories to different communication contexts.
  • Analyze and reflect on the ways in which communication impacts their daily lives in multicultural societies.
  • Present and communicate their findings and viewpoints in writing, oral presentation, and discussion.

course_title: Introduction to International and European Union Law
lecturers: ['dr. F Violi', 'dr. M Glavina', 'dr. M Markakis, MJur DPhil (Ox)', 'prof.dr. R Repasi', 'R de Geus, LL.M']

course_title: Introduction to International and European Union Law
lecturers: ['dr. F Violi', 'dr. M Glavina', 'dr. M Markakis, MJur DPhil (Ox)', 'prof.dr. R Repasi', 'R de Geus, LL.M']

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. L.W.J. Bosman', 'E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen']

text:
Inhoud The course Introduction to Law provides a general, broad introduction to the law and to the study of law. Students will learn about the foundations of liberal-democratic legal systems, the basic legal concepts and the sources of law. They will become acquainted with the main legal families of law, namely civil law and common law; with the differences between private law and public law; as well as the fundamentals of main areas of law such as criminal law, constitutional law, and administrative law which will be studied from a comparative perspective. In addition to these substantive issues, students will also learn about the specific methods used by lawyers to solve legal problems and reflect on the forms of argumentation lawyers use to defend their case. With the help of literature and real life examples from case law, students will understand how lawyers use universal forms of reasoning such as deduction, as well as specific forms like legal analogy, and argumentation based on principles.
  Leerdoelen
After completing this course, students will be able to:
  • Describe and explain the main concepts of law, such as public and private law, substantive and procedural law;
  • Describe, explain and critically evaluate the foundational concepts related to legitimate government;  specifically the ideals of a constitution, the rule of law, democracy, and the separation of powers;
  • Describe and explain the theoretical foundations of legal procedures and gain a global insight in Alternative Dispute Resolution;
  • Describe and explain the differences and convergences between civil law and common law;
  • Describe, explain and critically evaluate the main principles of criminal law;
  • Describe, explain and critically evaluate the main principles of contract law;
  • Conduct a simple legal research on a selected issue and present your findings both orally and in writing;
  • Argue in a case in a clear, structured and persuasive manner, both orally and in writing.

lecturers: ['APGCF Biard', 'KM Mikolajczyk, LLM']
text:
Inhoud This course provides a general introduction to the law and to the study of law. Students will become acquainted with the main fields of law: private law, criminal law, constitutional and administrative law. Specific attention will be paid to the basic differences between common law and civil law systems and to the relationship between national laws and European law. Besides the study and discussion of literature, students will train specific legal skills, such as the use of statutes, the analysis of judgments and the solution of legal cases. This course seeks to: 
1. Harmonize levels of understanding of law among lawyers and economists in the EMLE programme;
2. Facilitate among lawyers from various countries an understanding of basic legal concepts and doctrines across legal systems;
3. Introduce both lawyers & economists to legal concepts and methods that are instrumental in the field of law and economics

Inhoud
  • Properties of functions
  • Differentiation
  • Single variable optimization
  • Functions of many variables
  • Multivariable optimization
  • Constrained optimization
Leerdoelen
  • To obtain an understanding of the role that mathematics plays in the economic sciences
  • To deal with mathematics in such a way that in later years a student will be able to recognize which subject from mathematics is used and - if necessary - to study more advanced topics by her/himself

lecturers: ['KM Mikolajczyk, LLM', 'mr. I Jabri', 'mr.drs. AJ van Heusden', 'prof.mr.dr. LT Visscher']
text:
Inhoud

lecturers: ['dr. M Zhelonkin']
text:
Inhoud

The course is primarily theoretical. In this course we use a lot of linear algebra and see its connection with statistics. After the univariate statistics studied in the previous courses, we move to multivariate statistical methods. We start with the geometry of multivariate samples. Then we generalize the univariate methods to multivariate setting. And finally, we study several techniques that are useful in practice.

This course uses knowledge of FEB21023X Vector Calculus and FEB21007X(S) Statistics, and is required for FEB22004X Econometrics 1, FEB22017X Finance en FEB22018X Marketing.

Leerdoelen
  • Students get introduced to the geometry of multivariate samples.
  • Students get introduced to the multivariate normal distribution.
  • Students learn to apply some multivariate methods (estimation and tests) that involve the multivariate normal distribution.
  • Students learn the basis of principal components and factor analysis.

course_title: Introduction to Organizational Dynamics in the Digital Society
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. W van Zoonen', 'prof.dr. CL ter Hoeven']
text:
Inhoud Rapid advancements in technology, such as artificial intelligence, robotics, and algorithms, change the organisation of work. For example, algorithms can reorganise work practices and work design, robotization can change relationships and knowledge sharing among employees, and platformisation can influence our perceptions of organising and organisations. This raises questions on the individual, organisational, and societal level. In this course we will focus on these different levels of analysis, and develop analytical skills and insights to understand the implications of taking one of these perspectives.
 
In class, we will first evaluate relevant theories to study work, organisations, and technology (e.g., technological framing and sociomateriality). Second, we will discuss scholarly work specifically dealing with technologies which have been at the forefront of the popular and academic imagination, such as artificial intelligence, robotics, and algorithms. Finally, we will discuss how taking one perspective (e.g., psychological, sociological and/or public administration) will shed light on particular issues and consequences, while possibly disregarding others. In doing so, we will move from subjects such as work design and automation (e.g., Parker & Grote, 2020) to power relationships (e.g., Kellogg, Valentine, & Christin, 2020) and algorithmic control in the context of the ‘gig economy’ (e.g., Wood, Graham, Lehdonvirta, & Hjorth, 2019).
 
Students are encouraged to engage with the literature provided and also exchange their perspectives on the literature bringing in their BA backgrounds and possible previous work experiences. Finally, through a multi-disciplinary group assignment students will be invited to apply what they learned in practice, while an individual paper will provide room to develop personal ideas and critically reflect on a topic of choice. Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, students will:
  1. Be able to analyze how digital technologies might (re)shape the way we work, organize, and govern;
  2. Be able to reflect on technological change on the personal, organizational and societal level;
  3. Be familiar with different theoretical lenses to analyze work, organizations and technologies;
  4. Apply relevant theories related to organizations and technologies to real time situations and cases;
  5. Be able to critically reflect on different concerns and considerations related to technological interventions.

Inhoud Physics is the most basic of the sciences. It deals with the behaviour and structure of matter. The field of physics is usually divided into classical physics, which includes motion, fluids, heat, sound, light, electricity, and magnetism, and modern physics, which includes topics such as relativity, atomic structure, quantum theory, condensed matter and nuclear physics. The general aim of this course is to introduce you to the basic concepts of physics, and show you how important this scientific discipline is, not only for disciplines such as biology, medicine and architecture, but also in your everyday life.
  Leerdoelen

lecturers: ['dr. B Kuipers', 'dr. LM van der Lugt', 'drs. M Jansen', 'MA Streng', 'prof.dr. AW Veenstra', 'WAA Jacobs']
text:
Inhoud

There are many interesting economic issues and questions related to ports:

  • what kind of economic activities are conducted in ports?
  • What markets can be distinguished and what structure do they have?
  • How is an economic port cluster organized?
  • How is competition ensured or curtailed?
  • What determines the economic performance of ports and how can this be analysed and improved?
  • What role do transaction costs play?
  • How do ports or industrial clusters develop and grown?
  • Why do firms locate in ports?
  • What factors determine their performance?
  • Are there cluster advantages or disadvantages?

These are questions that will be dealt with in this course. For this purpose, we will rely on various relevant economic theories that can be applied to analyze and discuss these questions. We concentrate on the port as a node in transport and logistics networks, and as a location for industry. We will primarily look at this node or location from an economic point of view.

The course consists of a set of logically structured lectures in which - based upon real cases provided by the lecturers - students will engage in discussions on the economics of ports.

Leerdoelen

•To understand a port as a complex of or location for economic activity, and as nodes in transport and logistics networks where economic principles as competition, pricing, agglomeration, transactions and market integration work in a specific way.
•To analyse ports and their challenges from an economic point of view
•To apply various economic theories and constructs to analyse problems and challenges in ports and develop rational economic choices and organizational solutions.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The course was renewed and restructured completely last year. Besides some chnages in timing no major changes are foreseen. Extra The examination during this course is structured by a number of assignments that you will perform during the weeks. The course does not include an exam. So, your grade depends for 100% on your performance during the assignments.

lecturers: ['dr. NW Koning']
text:
Inhoud

The course starts by introducing the fundamental data types and operations. After that, control statements, i.e., decision and repetition, are presented. Then, methods, as computations consisting of multiple steps, are given. Lists and arrays, representing data structures storing multiple values, are depicted next. Last, the main concepts of object-oriented programming paradigm, i.e., class and instance, are described.
Meanwhile, students are expected to roll up their sleeves and acquire hands-on experience with the Java programming language. For this purpose, programming assignments will have to be completed by the students using a popular Integrated Development Environment (IDE). Students will develop an algorithmic way of thinking by implementing solutions for elementary computational problems in Econometrics.

This course is required for FEB21007X Statistics and FEB22012X Programming.

Leerdoelen

At the end of the course, students will:
· Understand the basic concepts of imperative programming.
· Understand the basic concepts of the object-oriented programming paradigm.
· Be able to write Java programs that solve elementary computational problems.
· Be able to use an Integrated Development Environment for writing and debugging Java programs.
· Be able to test whether the functionality of a program they implemented meets all the requirements.
· Be able to follow basic code-style principles to write readable code.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The release of chatGPT and similar software will have a huge impact on the course. We will incorporate this by encouraging students to play around with it and use it for their assignments. In addition, we will come with an extra assignment that goes beyond the level of the course in which the idea will be that students leverage chatGPT to write more complex programs.
